analyzed: hi yasmāt prajāpati suta upamāḥ te prasiddhāḥ kṛśāśvasya putrāḥ enam viśvāmitram anvacaran anucaranti sma atas putra snehena dattavān
translated: Hi, because. They, the sons of Kṛśāśva, who are well-known as the sons of Prajāpati, followed this Viśvāmitra. Therefore, out of affection for his sons, he gave (the kingdom).

original: iti bhāvaḥ // / ///
analyzed: iti bhāvaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: te putrāḥ ke ity apekṣāyām āha
analyzed: te putrāḥ ke iti apekṣāyām āha
translated: In anticipation of the question Who were those sons?, it is said:

original: jayā ca suprabhā caiva dākṣāyaṇyau sumadhyame / tayos tu yāny apatyāni śatam paramadurjayam // / ///
analyzed: jayā ca suprabhā ca eva dākṣāyaṇyau sumadhyame tayoḥ tu yāni apatyāni śatam parama durjayam
translated: Jayā and Suprabhā, the daughters of Dakṣa, of slender waists, had a hundred children, extremely invincible.

original: jayā ca suprabhā caiveti ye / dākṣāyaṇyau dakṣasya strīrūpe apatye / sumadhyame striyau /
analyzed: jayā ca suprabhā ca eva iti ye dākṣāyaṇyau dakṣasya strī rūpe apatye sumadhyame striyau
translated: Those who are called Jayā and Suprabhā, the daughters of Dakṣa in the form of women, were the two slender-waisted women.

original: āstām / tayoḥ yāni paramadurjayaṃ śataṃ apatyāni āsan / atra ca pūrvaślokāpekṣayottaravākyagatatvād
analyzed: āstām tayoḥ yāni parama durjayam śatam apatyāni āsan atra ca pūrvaśloka apekṣayā uttara vākya gata tvāt
translated: They had a hundred children, extremely invincible. And here, because of the dependence on the previous verse, the word that is not required in the subsequent sentence.

original: yacchabdasya tacchabdāpekṣā nāsti // / / //
analyzed: yad śabdasya tad śabda apekṣā na asti
translated: This is the meaning.

original: nanu kasyāḥ katy apatyāni āsann ity apekṣāyām āha
analyzed: nanu kasyāḥ kati apatyāni āsan iti apekṣāyām āha
translated: In anticipation of the question How many children did each have?, it is said:

original: pañcāśataḥ sutāñ jajñe jayā labdhavarā purā / vadhāyāsurasainyānāṃ te 'kṣayāḥ kāmarūpiṇaḥ // / /// Rām I /
analyzed: pañcāśataḥ sutām jajñe jayā labdha varā purā vadhāya asura sainyānām te kṣayāḥ kāmarūpiṇaḥ
translated: In ancient times, Jayā, who had obtained a boon, gave birth to fifty sons, who were inexhaustible and could assume any form at will, for the destruction of the armies of the demons.

original: akṣayāḥ nāśarahitāḥ // / ///
analyzed: akṣayāḥ nāśa rahitāḥ
translated: They were inexhaustible, free from destruction.🔽This is the meaning.

original: suprabhā janayām āsa putrān pañcāśataḥ parān / saṅgharṣān nāma durdharṣān durākrośān balīyasaḥ // / /// Rām I /
analyzed: suprabhā janayām āsa putrān pañcāśataḥ parān saṅgharṣān nāma durdharṣān durākrośān balīyasaḥ rām i
translated: Suprabhā gave birth to five hundred excellent sons, the invincible Saṅghāras, who were powerful and difficult to assail.

original: durdharṣān parābhavitum aśakyān / durākrośān śatrubhiḥ samare āhvātum aśakyān // / ///
analyzed: durdharṣān parābhavitum aśakyān durākrośān śatrubhiḥ samare āhvātum aśakyān
translated: Invincible, incapable of being overcome; difficult to assail, incapable of being challenged by enemies in battle.

original: prāsaṅgikam upasaṃhṛtya prakṛtam anusarati
analyzed: prāsaṅgikam upasaṃhṛtya prakṛtam anusarati
translated: Having concluded the incidental matter, he follows the main topic.

original: evaṃvīryo mahātejā viśvāmitro mahāmuniḥ / na rāmagamane buddhiṃ viklavāṃ kartum arhasi // / /// Rām I /
analyzed: evaṃvīryaḥ mahā tejāḥ viśvāmitraḥ mahā muniḥ na rāma gamane buddhim viklavām kartum arhasi rāma i
translated: Thus the great sage Viśvāmitra, of such prowess and great splendor, does not deserve to make your mind waver about Rāma's journey.

original: pūrvārdham uttarārdhasya hetutvena yojyam // / ///
analyzed: pūrva ardham uttara ardhasya hetu tvena yojyam
translated: The first half is to be connected as the reason for the second half.

original: sargāntaślokena śrīvasiṣṭho vākyaṃ samāpayati
analyzed: sarga anta ślokena śrī vasiṣṭhaḥ vākyam samāpayati
translated: With the concluding verse of the creation, Śrī Vasiṣṭha completes his statement:

original: asmin mahāsattvamaye munīndre sthite samīpe puruṣas tu sādhuḥ / prāpte 'pi mṛtyāv amaratvam eti mā dīnatāṃ gaccha yathā vimūḍhaḥ // / ///
analyzed: asmin mahāsattva maye muni indre sthite samīpe puruṣaḥ tu sādhuḥ prāpte mṛtyau amara tvam eti mā dīna tām gaccha yathā vimūḍhaḥ
translated: When this great-souled lord of sages is present nearby, a virtuous man attains immortality even when death has arrived. Do not become despondent like a fool.

original: yathā vimūḍhaḥ / mūḍhavad ity arthaḥ / iti śivam // / ///
analyzed: yathā vimūḍhaḥ mūḍha vat iti arthaḥ iti śivam
translated: Like a fool. The meaning is like a deluded one. Thus is auspicious.

original: iti śrībhāskarakaṇṭhaviracitāyāṃ śrīmokṣopāyaṭīkāyāṃ vairāgyaprakaraṇe aṣṭamaḥ sargaḥ // / //
analyzed: iti śrī bhāskarakaṇṭha viracitāyām śrī mokṣopāya ṭīkāyām vairāgya prakaraṇe aṣṭamaḥ sargaḥ  /
translated: Thus ends the eighth canto named the Description of the Forest in the great poem Moksopाय composed by Sri Bhashkarakantha.

original: śrīvālmīkir bharadvājam prati kathayati
analyzed: śrī vālmīkiḥ bharadvājam prati kathayati
translated: Valmiki tells Bharadvaja:

original: tathā vasiṣṭhe bruvati rājā daśarathaḥ sutam / samutsraṣṭumanā rāmam ājuhāva salakṣmaṇam // / /// Rām I /
analyzed: tathā vasiṣṭhe bruvati rājā daśarathaḥ sutam samutsraṣṭu manāḥ rāmam ājuhāva sa lakṣmaṇam rām i
translated: When Vasishtha was speaking thus, King Dasharatha, desirous of bestowing Rama, summoned him along with Lakshmana.

original: samutsraṣṭumanāḥ dātumanāḥ // / ///
analyzed: samutsraṣṭu manāḥ dātu manāḥ
translated: Desirous of bestowing means desirous of giving.

original: daśarathaḥ pratīhāram prati kathayati
analyzed: daśarathaḥ pratīhāram prati kathayati
translated: Dasharatha tells the doorkeeper:

original: pratīhāra mahābāhuṃ rāmam satyaparākramam / salakṣmaṇam avighnena munyarthaṃ śīghram ānaya // / ///
analyzed: pratīhāra mahā bāhum rāmam satya parākramam sa lakṣmaṇam avighnena muni artham śīghram ānaya
translated: O doorkeeper, bring the mighty-armed Rama, whose prowess is truth, along with Lakshmana, without any hindrance, quickly, for the sake of the sage.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: daśarathavākyam upasaṃharati
analyzed: daśaratha vākyam upasaṃharati
translated: He concludes Dasharatha's statement:

original: iti rājñā visṛṣṭo 'sau gatvāntaḥpuramandiram / muhūrtamātreṇāgatya samuvāca mahīpatim // / ///
analyzed: iti rājñā visṛṣṭaḥ sau gatvā antaḥpura mandiram muhūrta mātreṇa āgatya samuvāca mahīpatim
translated: Thus commanded by the king, he went to the inner palace, and returning in a moment, said to the king:

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: pratīhāraḥ kathayati
analyzed: pratīhāraḥ kathayati
translated: The doorkeeper says:

original: deva dordalitāśeṣaripo rāmaḥ svamandire / vimanāḥ saṃsthito rātrau ṣaṭpadaḥ kamale yathā // / ///🔽spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: deva dos dalita aśeṣa ripoḥ rāmaḥ sva mandire vimanāḥ saṃsthitaḥ rātrau ṣaṭpadaḥ kamale yathā 🔽spaṣṭam
translated: O Lord, Rama, who has crushed all enemies, is staying in his own palace at night, dispirited, like a bee in a lotus.

original: āgacchāmi kṣaṇeneti vakti dhyāyati caikakaḥ / na kasyacic ca nikaṭe sthātum icchati khinnadhīḥ // / ///
analyzed: āgacchāmi kṣaṇena iti vakti dhyāyati ca ekakaḥ na kasyacid ca nikaṭe sthātum icchati khinna dhīḥ
translated: He says, I will come in a moment, but thinks otherwise. With a weary mind, he does not wish to stay near anyone.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: ity ukte tena bhūpālas taṃ rāmānucaraṃ janam / sarvam āśvāsayām āsa papraccha ca yathākramam // / ///
analyzed: iti ukte tena bhūpālaḥ tam rāma anucaram janam sarvam āśvāsayām āsa papraccha ca yathākramam
translated: When this was said, the king comforted all the people who were followers of Rama, and asked them in due order.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: rājapraśnam eva kathayati
analyzed: rāja praśnam eva kathayati
translated: He narrates the king's questions.

original: kathaṃ kīdṛk sthito rāma iti pṛṣṭo mahībhṛtā / rāmabhṛtyajanaḥ khinno vākyam āha mahīpatim // / ///
analyzed: katham kīdṛś sthitaḥ rāmaḥ iti pṛṣṭaḥ mahībhṛtā rāma bhṛtya janaḥ khinnaḥ vākyam āha mahīpatim
translated: When asked by the king, How is Rama? What is he like? the people who served Rama, being weary, spoke to the king.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: dehayaṣṭim imāṃ deva dhārayanta ime vayam / khinnāḥ khedaparimlāne vibho rāme sute tava // / ///🔽he deva he rājan / dehayaṣṭiṃ dehalatāṃ / rāme rāmākhye / tava sute tava sutanimittaṃ / carmaṇi dvīpinaṃ hantītivat // / ///
analyzed: deha yaṣṭim imām deva dhārayantaḥ ime vayam khinnāḥ kheda parimlāne vibho rāme sute tava  he deva he rājan dehayaṣṭim deha latām rāme rāma ākhye tava sute tava suta nimittam carmaṇi dvīpinam hanti itivat
translated: O Lord, we are bearing this body-staff, but we are weary, O Lord, in your son Rama, who is languid with weariness.🔽O Lord, O king. The body-staff, the creeper of the body. In Rama, named Rama. For your son, for the sake of your son, like one who kills a leopard on the skin.

original: rāmo rājīvapatrākṣo yataḥprabhṛti cāgataḥ / savipras tīrthayātrāyās tataḥprabhṛti durmanāḥ // / ///
analyzed: rāmaḥ rājīva patra akṣaḥ yatas prabhṛti ca āgataḥ sa vipraḥ tīrtha yātrāyāḥ tatas prabhṛti durmanāḥ
translated: Since when has Rama, with eyes like lotus petals, along with the Brahmins, been unhappy, since he went on a pilgrimage?

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.🔽Since when has Rama, with eyes like lotus petals, along with the Brahmins, been unhappy, since he went on a pilgrimage?

original: yatnaprārthanayāsmākaṃ nijavyāpāram āhnikam / sāyam amlānavadanaḥ karoti na karoti vā // / ///
analyzed: yatna prārthanayā asmākam nija vyāpāram āhnikam sāyam amlāna vadanaḥ karoti na karoti vā
translated: Whether he performs his daily duties with effort and supplication, or with a face unfaded in the evening, he does or does not.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: snānadevārcanācāraparyante parikhedavān / prārthito 'pi hi nā tṛpter aśnāty aśanam īśvaraḥ // / ///
analyzed: snāna deva arcana ācāra paryante parikhedavān prārthitaḥ u pi hi nā tṛpteḥ aśnāti aśanam īśvaraḥ
translated: Even though requested, the Lord, tired from bathing, worshipping the gods, and other rituals, does not eat food to his satisfaction.

original: ā tṛpteḥ tṛptiparyantam // / ///
analyzed: ā tṛpteḥ tṛpti paryantam
translated: Up to satisfaction, up to the point of satisfaction.

original: lolāntaḥpuranārībhiḥ kṛtadolābhir aṅgane / na ca krīḍati līlābhir varādbhir iva cātakaḥ // / ///
analyzed: lola antaḥpura nārībhiḥ kṛta dolābhiḥ aṅgane  na ca krīḍati līlābhiḥ vara adbhiḥ iva cātakaḥ
translated: In the courtyard, he does not play with the swinging women of the harem, with their playful gestures, like a cataka bird with excellent water.

original: varādbhiḥ sarojalaiḥ / cātakaḥ pakṣiviśeṣaḥ / sa hi varṣābindūn eva pibati // / ///
analyzed: vara adbhiḥ saraḥ jalaiḥ cātakaḥ pakṣi viśeṣaḥ sa hi varṣā bindūn eva pibati
translated: With excellent water, with lotus water. The cataka bird is a particular bird. It drinks only rain drops.

original: māṇikyamuktāsamprotā keyūrakaṭakāvalī / nānandayati taṃ rājan dyauḥ pātavivaśaṃ yathā // / ///
analyzed: māṇikya muktā samprotā keyūra kaṭaka āvalī nā ānandayati tam rājan dyauḥ pāta vivaśam yathā
translated: A necklace studded with rubies and pearls, bracelets and armlets, do not delight him, O king, as the sky does one helpless in a fall.

original: pātavivaśam patantam // / ///
analyzed: pāta vivaśam patantam
translated: Helpless in a fall, falling.

original: krīḍadvadhūviloleṣu vahatkusumavāyuṣu / latāvalayageheṣu bhavaty ativiṣādavān // / ///
analyzed: krīḍat vadhū viloleṣu vahat kusuma vāyuṣu latā valaya geheṣu bhavati ati viṣādavān
translated: In the houses of vine arbors, where playful women sway and fragrant flower breezes blow, he is extremely sad.

original: latāvalayageheṣu latāmaṇḍalayukteṣu gṛheṣu // / ///
analyzed: latā valaya geheṣu latā maṇḍala yukteṣu gṛheṣu
translated: In the houses of vine arbors, in houses with vine mandalas.

original: yad ramyam ucitaṃ svādu peśalaṃ cittahāri vā / bāṣpapūrekṣaṇa iva tenaiva parikhidyate // / ///
analyzed: yat ramyam ucitam svādu peśalam citta hāri vā bāṣpa pūra īkṣaṇaḥ iva tena eva parikhidyate
translated: Whatever is delightful, suitable, tasty, pleasing, or captivating, he is troubled by it alone, as if his eyes were filled with tears.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: kim imā duḥkhadāyinyaḥ prasphuranti purogatāḥ / iti nṛttavilāseṣu kāminīḥ parinindati // / ///
analyzed: kim imāḥ duḥkha dāyinyaḥ prasphuranti purogatāḥ iti nṛtta vilāseṣu kāminīḥ parinindati
translated: He censures the women in the dances and entertainments, saying, Why do these givers of sorrow shine forth in front?

original: imāḥ etāḥ kāminyaḥ // / ///
analyzed: imāḥ etāḥ kāminyaḥ
translated: These are those women.

original: bhojanaṃ śayanam pānaṃ vilāsaṃ snānam āsanam / unmattaveṣṭitam iva nābhinandati ninditam // / ///
analyzed: bhojanam śayanam pānam vilāsam snānam āsanam unmatta veṣṭitam iva na abhinandati ninditam
translated: He does not delight in food, sleep, drink, enjoyment, bathing, or sitting, as if he were possessed by a demon, censuring what is condemned.

original: ninditaṃ nindāviṣayīkṛtam // / ///
analyzed: ninditam nindā viṣayīkṛtam
translated: What is condemned is made the object of censure.

original: kiṃ sampadā kiṃ vipadā kiṃ gehena kim īhitaiḥ / sarvam evāsad ity uktvā tūṣṇīm eko 'vatiṣṭhate // / ///
analyzed: kim sampadā kim vipadā kim gehena kim īhitaiḥ sarvam eva asat iti uktvā tūṣṇīm ekaḥ vatiṣṭhate
translated: What is the use of wealth, what is the use of misfortune, what is the use of a house, what is the use of desires? Having said that everything is false, he remains silent alone.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: nodeti parihāseṣu na bhogeṣu nimajjati / na ca tiṣṭhati kāryeṣu maunam evāvalambate // / ///
analyzed: na udeti parihāseṣu na bhogeṣu nimajjati na ca tiṣṭhati kāryeṣu maunam eva avalambate
translated: He does not rise to jokes, he does not sink into enjoyments, and he does not stand in duties, he resorts only to silence.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: vilolālakavallaryo helāvalitalocanāḥ / nānandayanti taṃ nāryo mṛgyo vanataruṃ yathā // / ///
analyzed: vilola alaka vallaryaḥ helā valita locanāḥ na ānandayanti tam nāryaḥ mṛgyaḥ vana tarum yathā
translated: The women with their tresses and creepers swaying, their eyes rolling playfully, do not delight him, like does not delight a tree in the forest.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: ekānteṣu diganteṣu tīreṣu vipineṣu ca / ratim āyāty araṇyeṣu vikrītavad ajantuṣu // / ///
analyzed: ekānteṣu diś anteṣu tīreṣu vipineṣu ca ratim āyāti araṇyeṣu vikrīta vat ajantuṣu
translated: He finds pleasure in solitary places, in the ends of the directions, on river banks, and in forests, as if he were sold, among creatures that are not human.

original: vikrīto hi palāyanārthaṃ janturahite eva deśe ratim āyāti // / ///
analyzed: vikrītaḥ hi palāyana artham jantu rahite eva deśe ratim āyāti
translated: For one who is sold, in order to escape, finds pleasure only in a place devoid of creatures.

original: vastrapānāśanādānaparāṅmukhatayā tayā / parivraḍdharmiṇāṃ rājan so 'nuyāti tapasvinām // / ///
analyzed: vastra pāna aśana ādāna parāṅmukha tayā tayā parivraj dharmiṇām rājan saḥ nu yāti tapasvinām
translated: By that aversion to accepting clothes, drinks, and food, O king, he follows the ascetics who have the dharma of wandering mendicants.

original: tapasvinām anuyāti tapasvisambandhicaritam anukarotīty arthaḥ / na māṣāṇām aśnīyād itivat prayogaḥ // / ///
analyzed: tapasvinām anuyāti tapasvi sambandhi caritam anukaroti iti arthaḥ na māṣāṇām aśnīyāt iti vat prayogaḥ
translated: He follows the ascetics; the meaning is that he imitates the conduct associated with ascetics. The usage is like he should not eat beans.

original: eka eva vasan deśe janaśūnye janeśvara / na hasaty ekayā buddhyā na gāyati na roditi // / ///
analyzed: ekaḥ eva vasan deśe jana śūnye janeśvara na hasati ekayā buddhyā na gāyati na roditi
translated: Dwelling alone in a country devoid of people, O lord of people, he does not laugh with a single thought, he does not sing, he does not weep.

original: ekayā buddhyā sarvatyāgarūpayā matyā upalakṣitaḥ // / ///
analyzed: ekayā buddhyā sarva tyāga rūpayā matyā upalakṣitaḥ
translated: Distinguished by a single thought, which is characterized by the renunciation of everything.

original: punaḥ kiṃ karotīty apekṣāyām āha
analyzed: punar kim karoti iti apekṣāyām āha
translated: Again, when there is expectation of what he does, it is said:

original: baddhapadmāsanaḥ śūnyamanā vāmakarasthale / kapolatalam ādāya kevalam paritiṣṭhati // / ///
analyzed: baddha padmāsanaḥ śūnya manāḥ vāma kara sthale kapola talam ādāya kevalam paritiṣṭhati
translated: Seated with crossed legs, with an empty mind, holding the cheek with the left hand, he simply remains.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: Clear.

original: nābhimānam upādatte nāpi vāñchati rājatām / nodeti nāstam āyāti sukhaduḥkhānuvṛttiṣu // / ///
analyzed: na abhimānam upādatte na api vāñchati rāja tām na udeti na astam āyāti sukha duḥkha anuvṛttiṣu
translated: He does not entertain pride, nor does he desire sovereignty. He does not rise or set in the course of happiness and sorrow.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: na vidmaḥ kim asau jātaḥ kiṃ karoti kim īhate / kiṃ dhyāyati kim āyāti kathaṃ kim anudhāvati // / ///
analyzed: na vidmaḥ kim asau jātaḥ kim karoti kim īhate kim dhyāyati kim āyāti katham kim anudhāvati
translated: We do not know what he is born for, what he does, what he desires, what he meditates, how he comes, or what he pursues.

original: na vidma ity asya karmāpekṣāyām āha kim asau jātaḥ kimartham asau jātaḥ / jananaṃ hi bhogādisevanārtham iti bhāvaḥ // / ///
analyzed: na vidmaḥ iti asya karma apekṣāyām āha kim asau jātaḥ kimartham asau jātaḥ jananam hi bhoga ādi sevana artham iti bhāvaḥ
translated: When there is expectation of the object of we do not know, he says: What is he born for? For what purpose is he born? For the meaning is that birth is for the sake of enjoying pleasures, etc.

original: pratyahaṃ kṛśatāṃ yāti pratyahaṃ yāti pāṇḍutām / virāgam pratyahaṃ yāti śaradanta iva drumaḥ // / ///
analyzed: pratyaham kṛśa tām yāti pratyaham yāti pāṇḍu tām  virāgam pratyaham yāti śarad antaḥ iva drumaḥ
translated: Day by day he becomes emaciated, day by day he becomes pale, day by day he becomes dispassionate, like a tree in autumn.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: anuyātau tam evaitau rājañ śatrughnalakṣmaṇau / tādṛśāv eva tasyaiva pratibimbāv iva sthitau // / ///
analyzed: anuyātau tam eva etau rājam śatrughna lakṣmaṇau tādṛśau eva tasya eva pratibimbau iva sthitau
translated: O king, these two, Satrughna and Lakshmana, follow him, standing as if they were the very images of him.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: bhṛtyai rājabhir ambābhiḥ sa pṛṣṭo 'pi punaḥ punaḥ / uktvā na kiñcid eveti tūṣṇīm āste nirīhitaḥ // / ///
analyzed: bhṛtyaiḥ rājabhiḥ ambābhiḥ sa pṛṣṭaḥ punar punar  uktvā na kiñcid evā iti tūṣṇīm āste nirīhitaḥ
translated: Though repeatedly asked by his servants, kings, and mothers, he, being disinterested, remains silent, saying nothing at all.

original: saḥ śrīrāmaḥ / nirīhitaḥ ceṣṭitarahitaḥ / itiśabdaḥ pādapūraṇārthaḥ śrīrāmottaravākyasvarūpanirdeśaparo vā jñeyaḥ // / ///
analyzed: saḥ śrī rāmaḥ nirīhitaḥ ceṣṭita rahitaḥ iti śabdaḥ pāda pūraṇa arthaḥ śrī rāma uttara vākya svarūpa nirdeśa paraḥ vā jñeyaḥ
translated: He is Sri Rama. Free from exertion, devoid of action. The word iti is to be known as serving the purpose of filling the foot or as indicating the form of the subsequent statement of Sri Rama.

original: āpātamātrahṛdyeṣu mā bhogeṣu manaḥ kṛthāḥ / iti pārśvagatam bhavyam anuśāsti suhṛjjanam // / ///
analyzed: āpāta mātra hṛdyeṣu mā bhogeṣu manaḥ kṛthāḥ iti pārśva gatam bhavyam anuśāsti suhṛd janam
translated: Do not set your mind on enjoyments that are pleasing only for the moment. Thus, the wise one instructs the good people who are at his side, as if they were present before him.

original: bhavyam anuśāsanayogyam // / ///
analyzed: bhavyam anuśāsana yogyam
translated: The good one is fit for instruction.

original: nānāvibhavaramyāsu strīṣu goṣṭhīkathāsu ca / puraḥsthitam ivāsneho nāśam evānupaśyati // / ///
analyzed: nānā vibhava ramyāsu strīṣu goṣṭhī kathāsu ca puras sthitam iva asnehaḥ nāśam eva anupaśyati
translated: In women who are charming with various ornaments, and in the conversations of cowherds, he sees only destruction, as if it were present before him, without attachment.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: rītimādhuryasāyāsapadasaṃsthitivarjitaiḥ / ceṣṭitair eva kākalyā bhūyo bhūyaḥ pragāyati // / ///
analyzed: rīti mādhurya sāyāsa pada saṃsthiti varjitaiḥ ceṣṭitaiḥ eva kākalyā bhūyas bhūyas pragāyati
translated: With actions devoid of style, sweetness, effort, and position, he sings again and again with the sweetness of his voice.

original: saḥ rāmaḥ / rītimādhuryasāyāsapadasaṃsthitivarjitaiḥ ceṣṭitair eva kevalaiḥ abhinayair evopalakṣitayā kākalyā kalasūkṣmadhvaninā / gāyati // / ///
analyzed: saḥ rāmaḥ rīti mādhurya sāyāsa pada saṃsthiti varjitaiḥ ceṣṭitaiḥ eva kevalaiḥ abhinayaiḥ eva upalakṣitayā kākalyā kala sūkṣma dhvaninā gāyati
translated: He, Rama, with actions alone devoid of style, sweetness, effort, and position, with the sweetness characterized by mere gestures, with a voice subtle like a kalapingala bird, he sings.

original: samrāḍ bhaveti pārśvasthaṃ vadantam anujīvinam / pralapantam ivonmattaṃ hasaty anyamanā muniḥ // / ///
analyzed: samrāj bhava iti pārśva stham vadantam anujīvinam pralapantam iva unmattam hasati anya manāḥ muniḥ
translated: To the dependent who says, You will become an emperor, the sage, whose mind is elsewhere, laughs, as if he were speaking nonsense, like a madman.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: Clear.

original: na proktam ākarṇayati prekṣate na purogatam / karoty avajñāṃ sarvatra sumahaty api vastuni // / ///
analyzed: na proktam ākarṇayati prekṣate na purogatam  karoti avajñām sarvatra su mahati api vastuni
translated: He does not listen to what is spoken, does not look at what is in front, shows contempt everywhere, even for a very great matter.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: Clear.

original: apy ākāśasarojinyām apy ākāśamahāvane / ittham etat katham iti vismayo 'sya na jāyate // / ///
analyzed: api ākāśa sarojinyām api ākāśa mahā vane ittham etat katham iti vismayaḥ sya na jāyate
translated: Even in the sky-lotus grove, even in the great sky-forest, he does not have this wonder: How is this?

original: vismayasya svarūpaṃ darśayati ittham etat katham iti // / ///
analyzed: vismayasya svarūpam darśayati ittham etat katham iti
translated: He shows the nature of wonder: How is this?

original: kāntāmadhyagatasyāpi mano 'sya madaneṣavaḥ / na bhedayanti durbhedaṃ dhārā iva mahopalam // / ///
analyzed: kāntā madhya gatasya api manaḥ sya madana iṣavaḥ na bhedayanti durbhedam dhārāḥ iva mahā upalam
translated: Even though he is in the midst of his beloved, the arrows of Cupid do not pierce his heart, which is hard to pierce, like a great rock by streams.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: Clear.

original: āpadām ekam āvāsam abhivāñchasi kiṃ dhanam / anuśāsyeti sarvasvam arthine samprayacchati // / ///
analyzed: āpadām ekam āvāsam abhivāñchasi kim dhanam anuśāsya iti sarva svam arthine samprayacchati
translated: Why do you desire wealth, which is the abode of only one misfortune? Having instructed thus, he gives all his possessions to the seeker.

original: anuśāsya anuśāsanaṃ kṛtvā // / ///
analyzed: anuśāsya anuśāsanam kṛtvā
translated: Having instructed, having given advice.

original: iyam āpad iyaṃ saṃpad ity ayaṃ kalpanāmayaḥ / manasy abhyudito moha iti śokāt pragāyati // / ///
analyzed: iyam āpad iyam saṃpad iti ayam kalpanā mayaḥ manasi abhyuditaḥ mohaḥ iti śokāt pragāyati
translated: This is misfortune, this is good fortune. This delusion, born of imagination, arises in the mind. Thus he sings out of sorrow.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: Clear.

original: hā hato 'ham anātho 'ham ity ākrandaparo 'pi san / na jano yāti vairāgyaṃ citram ity eva vakty asau // / ///
analyzed: hā hataḥ ham anāthaḥ ham iti ākranda paraḥ pi san na janaḥ yāti vairāgyam citram iti eva vakti asau
translated: Even while crying out, Alas! I am ruined! I am helpless! people do not attain detachment. Rather, they say, How wonderful!

original: ākrandaparasya vairāgyaṃ yuktam evety apiśabdena dyotyate // / ///
analyzed: ākranda parasya vairāgyam yuktam evā iti apiśabdena dyotyate
translated: The word api (even) indicates that detachment is indeed appropriate for one who is crying out.

original: raghukānanasālena rāmeṇa ripughātinā / bhṛśam itthaṃ sthitenaiva vayaṃ khedam upāgatāḥ // / ///
analyzed: raghu kānana sālena rāmeṇa ripu ghātinā bhṛśam ittham sthitena eva vayam khedam upāgatāḥ
translated: We have become greatly distressed by Rama, the slayer of enemies, who is like a forest of sugarcane, remaining thus.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: (The meaning is) clear.

original: na vidmaḥ kim mahābāho tasya tādṛśacetasaḥ / kurmaḥ kamalapatrākṣa gatir atra hi no bhavān // / ///
analyzed: na vidmaḥ kim mahā bāho tasya tādṛśa cetasaḥ kurmaḥ kamala patra akṣa gatiḥ atra hi naḥ bhavān
translated: O mighty-armed one, we do not know what to do with him who has such a mind. O lotus-eyed one, you are our guide in this matter.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: (The meaning is) clear.

original: rājānam atha vā vipram upadeṣṭāram agragam / hasan paśum ivāvyagraḥ so 'vadhīrayati prabho // / ///
analyzed: rājānam atha vā vipram upadeṣṭāram agragam  hasan paśum iva avyagraḥ saḥ vadhīrayati prabho
translated: Laughing like a beast, he disregards the king, the brahmin, the preceptor, or the leader. O lord,

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: (The meaning is) clear.

original: prapañco 'yam iha sphāraṃ jagannāma yad utthitam / naitad vastu na caivāham iti nirṇīya saṃsthitaḥ // / ///
analyzed: prapañcaḥ yam iha sphāram jagat nāma yat utthitam na etat vastu na ca eva aham iti nirṇīya saṃsthitaḥ
translated: This universe, which has arisen as the vast manifestation named the world, is not a real entity, and I am not it. Having ascertained this, one should remain.

original: yaḥ ayam prapañcaḥ utthitam idaṃ sphāraṃ jagannāma bhavati / etad vastu paramārthasat /
analyzed: yaḥ ayam prapañcaḥ utthitam idam sphāram jagat nāma bhavati etat vastu paramārtha sat
translated: This universe, which has arisen as the vast manifestation named the world, is a real entity in the ultimate sense.

original: na bhavati / evaśabdaḥ apiśabdasyārthe / aham api vastu na ca bhavāmi / iti evaṃ /
analyzed: na bhavati eva śabdaḥ api śabdasya arthe aham api vastu na ca bhavāmi iti evam
translated: It does not exist. The word eva (indeed) has the meaning of api (also). I also do not exist as an entity. Thus.

original: nirṇīyāsau rāmaḥ saṃsthitaḥ // / / //
analyzed: nirṇīya asau rāmaḥ saṃsthitaḥ
translated: Rama, having ascertained this, remains...🔽Not in the wife, not in the self, not in the friend, not in the kingdom, not in the mother,

original: nārau nātmani no mitre na rājye na ca mātari / na saṃpadāpador nāntas tasyāsthā na vibhor bahiḥ // / ///
analyzed: na arau na ātmani no mitre na rājye na ca mātari na saṃpad āpadoḥ nā antar tasya āsthā na vibhoḥ bahis
translated: Not in prosperity or adversity, not within, nor does he have a foothold outside the lord...

original: āsthā ratiḥ // / ///
analyzed: āsthā ratiḥ
translated: Asta (foothold) means delight...🔽He who is free from foothold, hope, effort, and support,

original: nirastāstho nirāśo 'sau nirīho 'sau nirāspadaḥ / mohe na ca vimukto 'sau tena tapyāmahe vayam // / ///
analyzed: nirasta āsthaḥ nirāśaḥ sau nirīhaḥ sau nirāspadaḥ  mohe na ca vimuktaḥ sau tena tapyāmahe vayam
translated: And is not liberated from delusion, by him we are tormented...

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear...🔽What is the use of wealth, what of mothers, what of kingdom, what of striving?

original: kiṃ dhanena kim ambābhiḥ kiṃ rājyena kim īhayā / iti niścayavān antaḥ prāṇatyāgamanāḥ sthitaḥ // / ///
analyzed: kim dhanena kim ambābhiḥ kim rājyena kim īhayā iti niścayavān antar prāṇatyāga manāḥ sthitaḥ
translated: Thus resolved within, he remains ready to give up his life...

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear...🔽He has become extremely anxious about enjoyments, life, kingdom, friend, father, and mother,

original: bhogeṣv āyuṣi rājye ca mitre pitari mātari / param udvegam āyātaś cātako 'vagrahe yathā // / ///
analyzed: bhogeṣu āyuṣi rājye ca mitre pitari mātari param udvegam āyātaḥ cātakaḥ vagrahe yathā
translated: Like a chakravaka bird during a cloud...

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear...🔽To him who has such a nature, endowed with all prosperity,

original: tasya tādṛksvabhāvasya samagravibhavānvitam / saṃsārajālam ābhogi prabho prativiṣāyate // / ///
analyzed: tasya tādṛś svabhāvasya samagra vibhava anvitam saṃsāra jālam ābhogi prabho prativiṣāyate
translated: The world with its net of existence appears as poison, O Lord...

original: prativiṣam ivācarate prativiṣāyate // / ///
analyzed: prativiṣam iva ācarate prativiṣāyate
translated: He acts like an antidote, he becomes like an antidote.

original: tādṛśaḥ syān mahāsattvaḥ ka ivāsmin mahītale / prakṛte vyavahāre taṃ yo niveśayituṃ kṣamaḥ // / ///
analyzed: tādṛśaḥ syāt mahāsattvaḥ kaḥ iva asmin mahī tale prakṛte vyavahāre tam yaḥ niveśayitum kṣamaḥ
translated: Such a great being would be, who on this earth is able to establish him in the natural worldly conduct?

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: iti no yeyam āyātā śākhāprasaraśālinī / āpat tām alam uddhartuṃ samudetu dayā parā // / ///
analyzed: iti naḥ yā iyam āyātā śākhā prasara śālinī āpad tām alam uddhartum samudetu dayā parā
translated: Thus, this calamity that has befallen us, spreading out like branches, may the great compassion arise to completely remove it.

original: samudetu taveti śeṣaḥ // / ///
analyzed: samudetu tava iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is may it arise for you.

original: sargāntaślokena rāmabhṛtyavacanaṃ samāpayati
analyzed: sarga anta ślokena rāma bhṛtya vacanam samāpayati
translated: With the concluding verse of the creation, he concludes Rama's speech:

original: manasi moham apāsya mahāmanāḥ sakalam ārtimataḥ kila sādhutām / saphalatāṃ nayatīha tamo haran dinakaro bhuvi bhāskaratām iva // / ///
analyzed: manasi moham apāsya mahāmanāḥ sakalam ārtimataḥ kila sādhu tām saphala tām nayati iha tamaḥ haran dinakaraḥ bhuvi bhāskara tām iva
translated: The great-minded one, having removed delusion from the mind, indeed brings the goodness of the afflicted one to fruition in this world, like the sun, removing darkness, brings sunlight to the earth.

original: mahāmanāḥ puruṣaḥ / ārtimataḥ ārtiyuktasya puruṣasya / manasi sakalam moham ārtisvarūpaṃ
analyzed: mahāmanāḥ puruṣaḥ ārtimataḥ ārti yuktasya puruṣasya manasi sakalam moham ārti svarūpam
translated: The great-minded one is a man. Of the afflicted one, the one afflicted with sorrow, in the mind, all delusion, of the nature of sorrow,🔽all delusion. Having removed, having distanced, the goodness, the goodness present in oneself,

original: samastam moham / apāsya dūrīkṛtya / sādhutām svasmin sthitaṃ sādhubhāvaṃ / saphalatāṃ
analyzed: samastam moham apāsya dūrīkṛtya sādhu tām svasmin sthitam sādhu bhāvam saphala tām
translated: to fruition.

original: nayati / ka iva / dinakara iva / yathā dinakaraḥ bhuvi tamaḥ haran bhāskaratām saphalatāṃ
analyzed: nayati kaḥ iva dinakara iva yathā dinakaraḥ bhuvi tamaḥ haran bhāskara tām saphala tām
translated: He leads. Like what? Like the sun. Just as the sun, removing darkness from the earth, leads to the state of the sun, to the state of fruition,

original: nayati / tathety arthaḥ / iti śivam // / / //
analyzed: nayati tathā iti arthaḥ iti śivam
translated: so is the meaning. Thus is auspiciousness.

original: iti śrībhāskarakaṇṭhaviracitāyāṃ śrīmokṣopāyaṭīkāyāṃ vairāgyaprakaraṇe navamaḥ sargaḥ // / //
analyzed: iti śrī bhāskarakaṇṭha viracitāyām śrī mokṣopāya ṭīkāyām vairāgya prakaraṇe navamaḥ sargaḥ  /
translated: Thus ends the ninth chapter in the commentary of Shri Moksopāya composed by Shri Bhāskarakaṇṭha, in the section on non-attachment.

original: rāmabhṛtyavacanaṃ śrutvā viśvāmitraḥ kathayati
analyzed: rāma bhṛtya vacanam śrutvā viśvāmitraḥ kathayati
translated: Having heard the words of Rāmabhaṭṭa, Viśvāmitra says:

original: evaṃ cet tan mahāprājñam bhavanto raghunandanam / ihānayantu tvaritaṃ hariṇaṃ hariṇā iva // / ///
analyzed: evam ced tat mahā prājñam bhavantaḥ raghunandanam iha ānayantu tvaritam hariṇam hariṇāḥ iva
translated: If so, O wise ones, bring the descendant of Raghu here quickly, like deer by a lion.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: Clear.

original: eṣa moho raghupater nāpadbhyo na ca rāgataḥ / vivekavairāgyakṛto bodha eṣa mahodayaḥ // / ///
analyzed: eṣa mohaḥ raghu pateḥ na āpadbhyaḥ na ca rāgataḥ viveka vairāgya kṛtaḥ bodhaḥ eṣa mahā udayaḥ
translated: This is the delusion of the lord of Raghu, not due to calamities or passion, this is the great rise of enlightenment created by discrimination and detachment.

original: mahān udayaḥ muktilakṣaṇaḥ yasmāt saḥ mahodayaḥ // / ///
analyzed: mahān udayaḥ mukti lakṣaṇaḥ yasmāt saḥ mahodayaḥ
translated: Great rise is that which has the characteristic of liberation.

original: ihāyātu kṣaṇād rāmas tad ihaiva vayaṃ kṣaṇāt / mohaṃ tasyāpaneṣyāmo maruto 'drer ghanaṃ yathā // / ///
analyzed: iha āyātu kṣaṇāt rāmaḥ tat iha eva vayam kṣaṇāt moham tasya apaneṣyāmaḥ marutaḥ dreḥ ghanam yathā
translated: Let Rāma come here in a moment, let us be here in a moment, we will remove his delusion like the Maruts remove the cloud from the mountain.

original: vayaṃ ke iva / maruta iva / yathā marutaḥ vāyavaḥ / adreḥ ghanaṃ megham / apanayanti / tathety arthaḥ // / ///
analyzed: vayam ke iva marutaḥ iva yathā marutaḥ vāyavaḥ adreḥ ghanam megham apanayanti tathā iti arthaḥ
translated: Who are we? Like the Maruts. Just as the Maruts, the winds, remove the cloud from the mountain, so do we. This is the meaning.

original: etasmin mārjite yuktyā mohe ca raghunandanaḥ / viśrāntim eṣyati pade tasmin vayam ivottame // / ///
analyzed: etasmin mārjite yuktyā mohe ca raghunandanaḥ viśrāntim eṣyati pade tasmin vayam iva uttame
translated: When that is cleansed by reasoning, the descendant of Raghu will attain rest in that supreme state, just as we have.

original: tasmin pade cinmātrākhye viśrāntisthāne // / ///
analyzed: tasmin pade cit mātra ākhye viśrānti sthāne
translated: In that state called pure consciousness, the place of rest...

original: satyatām muditām prajñāṃ viśrāntiṃ ca sametya saḥ / pīnatāṃ varavarṇatvam pītāmṛta ivaiṣyati // / ///
analyzed: satya tām mudi tām prajñām viśrāntim ca sametya saḥ pīna tām varavarṇa tvam pīta amṛtaḥ iva eṣyati
translated: Having attained truth, joy, wisdom, and rest, he will attain fullness, the best complexion, like one who has drunk nectar.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: nijāṃ ca prakṛtām eva vyavahāraparamparām / paripūrṇamanā mānya ācariṣyaty akhaṇḍitām // / ///
analyzed: nijām ca prakṛtām eva vyavahāra paramparām paripūrṇa manāḥ mānyaḥ ācariṣyati akhaṇḍitām
translated: And he will continue his own habitual course of conduct, with a fully contented mind, unbroken.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: bhaviṣyati mahāsattvo jñātalokaparāvaraḥ / sukhaduḥkhadaśāhīnaḥ samaloṣṭāśmakāñcanaḥ // / /// BhG VI / XIV
analyzed: bhaviṣyati mahāsattvaḥ jñāta loka parāvaraḥ sukha duḥkha daśā hīnaḥ sama loṣṭa aśma kāñcanaḥ
translated: He will become a great being, who has known the highest and the lowest worlds, free from states of happiness and sorrow, regarding a clod of earth, a stone, and gold as the same.

original: jñāte samyak niścite / lokānām parāvare parāvācī / pāradvayam iti yāvat / yena / saḥ // / ///
analyzed: jñāte samyak niścite  lokānām parāvare parāvācī pāradvayam iti yāvat yena saḥ
translated: By whom the highest and the lowest worlds are well known and ascertained. The highest and the lowest worlds are the two shores, that is, the meaning is that he is one who has known the two shores.

original: viśvāmitravākyam upasaṃharati
analyzed: viśvāmitra vākyam upasaṃharati
translated: He concludes Vishvamitra's statement

original: ity ukte munināthena rājā sampūrṇamānasaḥ / prāhiṇod rāmam ānetum bhūyo dūtaparamparām // / ///
analyzed: iti ukte muni nāthena rājā sampūrṇa mānasaḥ prāhiṇot rāmam ānetum bhūyas dūta paramparām
translated: When this was said by the lord of sages, the king, with his mind fully satisfied, again sent a series of messengers to bring Rama.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: (The rest is clear.)

original: etāvatā ca kālena rāmo nijagṛhāsanāt / pituḥ sakāśam āgantum utthito 'rka ivācalāt // / ///
analyzed: etāvatā ca kālena rāmaḥ nija gṛha āsanāt pituḥ sakāśam āgantum utthitaḥ rkaḥ iva acalāt
translated: And in this much time, Rama rose from his seat in his own house to come into the presence of his father, like the sun from the mountain.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: (The rest is clear.)

original: vṛtaḥ katipayair bhṛtyair bhrātṛbhyāṃ cājagāma ha / tat puṇyam pitur āsthānaṃ svargaṃ surapater iva // / ///
analyzed: vṛtaḥ katipayaiḥ bhṛtyaiḥ bhrātṛbhyām ca ājagāma ha tat puṇyam pituḥ āsthānam svargam surapateḥ iva
translated: Surrounded by a few servants and his two brothers, he came to his father's auspicious assembly hall, like Indra to heaven.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: (The rest is clear.)

original: dūrād eva dadarśāsau rāmo daśarathaṃ tadā / vṛtaṃ rājasamūhena devaugheneva vāsavam // / ///
analyzed: dūrāt eva dadarśa asau rāmaḥ daśaratham tadā vṛtam rāja samūhena deva oghena iva vāsavam
translated: From a distance, Rama then saw Dasharatha, surrounded by a group of kings, like Indra by a multitude of gods.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: (The rest is clear.)

original: vasiṣṭhaviśvāmitrābhyāṃ sevitam pārśvayor dvayoḥ / sarvaśāstrārthatajjñena mantrivṛndena pālitam // / ///
analyzed: vasiṣṭha viśvāmitrābhyām sevitam pārśvayoḥ dvayoḥ sarva śāstra artha tad jñena mantri vṛndena pālitam
translated: Served on both sides by Vasishtha and Vishvamitra, protected by a multitude of ministers who know the meaning of all the scriptures,

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: (The rest is clear.)

original: cārucāmarahastābhiḥ kāntābhiḥ samupāsitam /
analyzed: cāru cāmara hastābhiḥ kāntābhiḥ samupāsitam
translated: Attended by beautiful women with lovely chamaras in their hands,

original: kakubbhir iva mūrtābhiḥ saṃsthitābhir yathocitam // / ///
analyzed: kakubbhiḥ iva mūrtābhiḥ saṃsthitābhiḥ yathocitam
translated: like the directions personified standing in their proper places.

original: kakubbhiḥ digbhiḥ // / ///
analyzed: kakubbhiḥ digbhiḥ
translated: By the directions.

original: vasiṣṭhaviśvāmitrādyās tathā daśarathādayaḥ / dadṛśū rāghavaṃ dūrād upāyāntaṃ guhopamam // / ///
analyzed: vasiṣṭha viśvāmitra ādyāḥ tathā daśaratha ādayaḥ dadṛśuḥ rāghavam dūrāt upāyāntam guhā upamam
translated: Vashishtha, Vishvamitra, and others, as well as Dasharatha and others, saw Raghava coming from a distance, resembling Guha.

original: guhopamaṃ kumārasadṛśam // / ///
analyzed: guhā upamam kumāra sadṛśam
translated: Resembling Guha, like a young boy.

original: sattvāvaṣṭambhagarveṇa śaityeneva himālayam / śritaṃ sakalasevyena gambhīreṇa svareṇa ca // / ///
analyzed: sattva avaṣṭambha garveṇa śaityena iva himālayam śritam sakala sevyena gambhīreṇa svareṇa ca
translated: With the pride of the firmness of his spirit, like the Himalayas with its coolness, and with his deep voice, which is resorted to by all,

original: sattvasyāvaṣṭambhena hastāvalambena yaḥ garvaḥ / tena / pūrvasya ślokasya viśeṣaṇatvena yojyam // / ///
analyzed: sattvasya avaṣṭambhena hasta avalambena yaḥ garvaḥ tena pūrvasya ślokasya viśeṣaṇa tvena yojyam
translated: With the pride that comes from the firmness of his spirit, the support of his hand. It should be connected as a qualification for the previous verse.

original: saumyaṃ samaśubhākāraṃ vinayodāram ūrjitam / kāntopaśāntavapuṣam parasyārthasya bhājanam // / ///
analyzed: saumyam sama śubha ākāram vinaya udāram ūrjitam kānta upaśānta vapuṣam parasya arthasya bhājanam
translated: Gentle, with a pleasant and auspicious appearance, humble yet majestic, powerful, with a body that is lovely and peaceful, a vessel for the welfare of others.

original: parasyārthasya mokṣasya // / ///
analyzed: parasya arthasya mokṣasya
translated: For the welfare of others, for liberation.

original: samudyadyauvanārambham udyogaśamaśobhitam / anudvignam anāyāsam pūrṇaprāyamanoratham // / ///
analyzed: samudyat yauvana ārambham udyoga śama śobhitam an udvignam an āyāsam pūrṇa prāya manoratham
translated: With the beginning of rising youth, adorned with the splendor of exertion and peace, free from anxiety, effortless, with almost all desires fulfilled.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: Clear.

original: vicāritajagadyātram pavitraguṇagocaram / mahāsattvaikalobhena guṇair iva samāśritam // / ///
analyzed: vicārita jagat yātram pavitra guṇa gocaram mahāsattva eka lobhena guṇaiḥ iva samāśritam
translated: With the course of the world considered, the sphere of pure qualities, resorted to as if by qualities alone, with the sole greed of great spirit.

original: mahāsattvasya mahādhairyasya / yaḥ eko lobhaḥ / tatsaṅgalobhaḥ iti yāvat / tena // / ///
analyzed: mahā sattvasya mahā dhairyasya yaḥ ekaḥ lobhaḥ tad saṅga lobhaḥ iti yāvat tena
translated: of the great being, of the one of great fortitude, who is the one greed, that is, attachment to greed, by that.

original: udārasāram āpūrṇam antaḥkaraṇakoṭaram / avikṣubhitayā vṛttyā darśayantam anuttamam // / ///
analyzed: udāra sāram āpūrṇam antaḥkaraṇa koṭaram a vikṣubhitayā vṛttyā darśayantam anuttamam
translated: Displaying the unsurpassed [Rama] with an unagitated state of mind, whose inner recesses are filled with noble essence.

original: rāmam punaḥ kathambhūtam / īdṛśyā vṛttyā īdṛśam antaḥkaraṇaṃ darśayantam iti sambandhaḥ / āpūrṇam bhogān prati alaulyena samantāt pūrṇam // / ///
analyzed: rāmam punar kathambhūtam īdṛśyā vṛttyā īdṛśam antaḥkaraṇam darśayantam iti sambandhaḥ āpūrṇam bhogān prati a laulyena samantāt pūrṇam
translated: Again, what is Rama like? The connection is: displaying such an inner state with such a state of mind. Filled with enjoyment, completely full due to lack of greed.

original: śrīrāmaviśeṣaṇāny upasaṃharati
analyzed: śrī rāma viśeṣaṇāni upasaṃharati
translated: He concludes the descriptions of Sri Rama.

original: evam guṇagaṇākīrṇo dūrād eva raghūdvahaḥ / parimeyasitācchācchasvahārāmbarapallavaḥ // / ///
analyzed: evam guṇa gaṇa ākīrṇaḥ dūrāt eva raghūdvahaḥ parimeya sita accha accha sva hāra ambara pallavaḥ
translated: Thus, the descendant of Raghu, filled with many virtues, from afar, with his own white, clear, garment-like leaves,

original: praṇanāma calaccārucūḍāmaṇimarīcinā / śirasā vasudhākampalolamānācalaśriyā // / ///
analyzed: praṇanāma calat cāru cūḍāmaṇi marīcinā śirasā vasudhā kampa lola māna acala śriyā
translated: bowed his head, with the rays of the moving, beautiful crest-jewel, with the glory of the moving mountain, which trembles with the trembling of the earth.

original: parimeyāḥ parimitāḥ / sitāḥ acchācchāḥ svahārāmbarapallavāḥ yasya / saḥ tādṛśaḥ /
analyzed: parimeyāḥ parimitāḥ sitāḥ accha acchāḥ sva hāra ambara pallavāḥ yasya saḥ tādṛśaḥ
translated: Whose own white, clear, garment-like leaves are limited, that is, measured.

original: śirasā kathambhūtena / vasudhāyāṃ yaḥ kampaḥ / tena lolamānasyācalasya śrīḥ yasya /
analyzed: śirasā kathambhūtena vasudhāyām yaḥ kampaḥ tena lolamānasya acalasya śrīḥ yasya
translated: What is the head like? The glory of the mountain, which moves with the trembling of the earth.

original: tat / tādṛśena / yugmam // / / //
analyzed: tat tādṛśena yugmam
translated: That. Such. A pair.

original: kān praṇanāmety apekṣāyām āha
analyzed: kān praṇanāma iti apekṣāyām āha
translated: When there is expectation of whom to bow to, he says

original: prathamam pitaram paścān munīn mānyaikam ānataḥ / tato viprāṃs tato bandhūṃs tato 'dhikaguṇān gurūn // / ///
analyzed: prathamam pitaram paścāt munīn mānya ekam ānataḥ tatas viprān tatas bandhūn tatas dhika guṇān gurūn
translated: First, with humility, the father, then the sages, the only one to be honored, then the Brahmins, then the relatives, then the gurus with superior qualities.

original: pitaraṃ kathambhūtaṃ / mānyānām madhye ekam mānyaikam // / ///
analyzed: pitaram kathambhūtam mānyānām madhye ekam mānya ekam
translated: What is the father like? The only one to be honored among those to be honored.

original: jagrāha cātmanā dṛṣṭvā manāk svādugirā tathā / rājalokena vihitāṃ sa praṇāmaparasparām // / ///
analyzed: jagrāha ca ātmanā dṛṣṭvā manāk svādu girā tathā rāja lokena vihitām sa praṇāma parasparām
translated: And he accepted the mutual salutations offered by the king's people, having seen them with his own eyes, with words of slight sweetness.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: vihitāśīr munibhyāṃ tu rāmaḥ saśamamānasaḥ / āsasāda pituḥ puṇyaṃ samīpaṃ surasundaraḥ // / ///
analyzed: vihita āśīḥ munibhyām tu rāmaḥ sa śama mānasaḥ āsasāda pituḥ puṇyam samīpam surasundaraḥ
translated: Then Rama, his mind at peace, his blessings given by the sages, approached the sacred presence of his father, the most handsome of the gods.

original: samīpaṃ nikaṭam // / ///
analyzed: samīpam nikaṭam
translated: Presence means nearness.

original: pādābhivandanarataṃ tam athāsau mahīpatiḥ / śirasy abhyāliliṅgāśu cucumba ca punaḥ punaḥ // / ///
analyzed: pāda abhivandana ratam tam atha asau mahīpatiḥ śirasi abhyāliliṅga āśu cucumba ca punar punar
translated: Then that lord of the earth quickly embraced him, who was devoted to bowing at his feet, and kissed him again and again.

original: śatrughnaṃ lakṣmaṇaṃ caiva tathaiva paravīrahā / āliliṅga ghanasnehaṃ rājahaṃso 'mbujaṃ yathā // / ///
analyzed: śatrughnam lakṣmaṇam ca eva tathā eva para vīra hā  āliliṅga ghana sneham rājahaṃsaḥ mbujam yathā
translated: And Shatrughna and Lakshmana, the slayer of enemy heroes, embraced him with deep affection, like a royal swan an lotus.

original: spaṣṭam / yugmam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam yugmam
translated: It is clear. A pair.

original: utsaṅge vatsa tiṣṭheti vadaty atha mahīpatau / bhūmau parijanāstīrṇe so 'ṃśuke 'tha nyavikṣata // / ///
analyzed: utsaṅge vatsa tiṣṭha iti vadati atha mahīpatau bhūmau parijana āstīrṇe nyavikṣata
translated: When the king said, My child, sit on my lap, he sat down on a cloth spread on the ground by the attendants.

original: nyavikṣata upāviśat / athaśabdadvayaṃ sambandhibhedenānantaryadvayavācakam // / ///
analyzed: nyavikṣata upāviśat
translated: He sat down. The word atha (then) is used to denote two consecutive events, each related to a different subject.

original: daśarathaḥ kathayati
analyzed: daśarathaḥ kathayati
translated: Dasharatha said:

original: putra prāptavivekas tvaṃ kalyāṇānāṃ ca bhājanam / janavaj jīrṇayā buddhyā khedāyātmā na dīyate // / ///
analyzed: putra prāpta vivekaḥ tvam kalyāṇānām ca bhājanam jana vat jīrṇayā buddhyā khedāya ātmā na dīyate
translated: O son, you have attained discrimination and are a receptacle of good things. The self is not given to weariness by an old intellect like that of the people.

original: tvayā na dīyate na deya ity arthaḥ / khedāyeti sampradāne caturthī // / ///
analyzed: tvayā na dīyate na deyaḥ iti arthaḥ khedāya iti sampradāne caturthī
translated: You do not give, meaning it should not be given. In for weariness, the fourth case is used for the recipient.

original: vṛddhavipraguruproktaṃ tvādṛśenānutiṣṭhatā / padam āsādyate puṇyaṃ na moham anudhāvatā // / ///
analyzed: vṛddha vipra guru proktam tvādṛśena anutiṣṭhatā padam āsādyate puṇyam na moham anudhāvatā
translated: By one like you who acts according to the words of old Brahmins and teachers, merit is attained, not by one who follows delusion.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: tāvad evāpado dūre tiṣṭhanti paripelavāḥ / yāvad eva na mohasya prasaraḥ putra dīyate // / ///🔽spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: tāvat eva āpadaḥ dūre tiṣṭhanti paripelavāḥ yāvat eva na mohasya prasaraḥ putra dīyate  spaṣṭam
translated: As long as delusion is not given scope, O son, calamities remain far away and insignificant.🔽 It is clear.

original: śrīvasiṣṭhaḥ kathayati
analyzed: śrī vasiṣṭhaḥ kathayati
translated: Sri Vasishtha said:

original: rājaputra mahābāho śūras tvaṃ vijitās tvayā / durucchedā durārambhā apy amī viṣayārayaḥ // / ///
analyzed: rāja putra mahā bāho śūraḥ tvam vijitāḥ tvayā durucchedāḥ durārambhāḥ api amī viṣaya arayaḥ
translated: O prince of mighty arms, you are a hero, you have conquered (the enemies). Even these enemies of sensual pleasures, difficult to cut off and difficult to undertake, are (conquered by you).

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: (The meaning is) clear.

original: kim atajjña ivājñānāṃ yogye vā mohasāgare / vinimajjasi kallolagahane jāḍyaśālini // / ///
analyzed: kim a tajjñaḥ iva ajñānām yogye vā moha sāgare vinimajjasi kallola gahane jāḍya śālini
translated: Why do you sink in the ocean of delusion, which is fit for the ignorant as if you were ignorant, in the dense waves of dullness, in the ocean of delusion?

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: (The meaning is) clear.

original: viśvāmitra āha
analyzed: viśvāmitraḥ āha
translated: Visvamitra said:

original: calannīlotpalavyūhasamalocana lolatām / brūhi cetaḥkṛtāṃ tyaktvā hetunā kena muhyasi // / ///
analyzed: calat nīlotpala vyūha sama locana lola tām brūhi cetaḥ kṛtām tyaktvā hetunā kena muhyasi
translated: O you whose eyes are like moving clusters of blue lotuses, having abandoned the fickleness created by the mind, tell (me), for what reason do you become deluded?

original: he calannīlotpalavyūhasamalocana tvaṃ / cetaḥkṛtāṃ lolatāṃ tyaktvā brūhi / karmāpekṣāyāṃ vākyaṃ karmatvena kathayati hetuneti / tvaṃ kimarthaṃ
analyzed: he calat nīlotpala vyūha sama locana tvam cetaḥ kṛtām lola tām tyaktvā brūhi karma apekṣāyām vākyam karma tvena kathayati hetunā iti tvam kimartham
translated: O you whose eyes are like moving clusters of blue lotuses, having abandoned the fickleness created by the mind, tell (me). In the case of dependence on action, he speaks the sentence as an action with the word 'hetu' (reason). The meaning is: for what purpose

original: muhyasīty arthaḥ // / ///🔽kiṃniṣṭhāḥ kiyatā kena kiyantaḥ kāraṇena te / ādhayo nu vilumpanti mano geham ivākhavaḥ // / ///
analyzed: muhyasi iti arthaḥ  kiṃniṣṭhāḥ kiyatā kena kiyantaḥ kāraṇena te ādhayaḥ nu vilumpanti manaḥ geham iva ākhavaḥ
translated: do you become deluded?🔽By what are they based? By how much? By what? How many are they? By what cause do those mental afflictions destroy the mind, like a house (is destroyed) by mice?

original: te kiyantaḥ ādhayaḥ / kiṃniṣṭhāḥ kiṃviṣayāḥ santaḥ / kiyatā kena kāraṇena manaḥ nu
analyzed: te kiyantaḥ ādhayaḥ kiṃniṣṭhāḥ kiṃviṣayāḥ santaḥ kiyatā kena kāraṇena manaḥ nu
translated: How many are those mental afflictions? Based on what? With what as their object? By how much? By what cause do they

original: vilumpanti / ke iva / ākhava iva / yathā ākhavaḥ gehaṃ vilumpanti / tathety arthaḥ /
analyzed: vilumpanti ke iva ākhavaḥ iva yathā ākhavaḥ geham vilumpanti tathā iti arthaḥ
translated: Who are they like? Like mice. Just as mice destroy a house, that is the meaning.

original: nuśabdaḥ praśnadyotakaḥ // / / //
analyzed: nu śabdaḥ praśna dyotakaḥ
translated: The word 'nu' indicates a question.🔽I think you are not the highest position for those who are not suitable,

original: manye nānucitānāṃ tvam ādhīnām padam uttamaḥ / āpatsu cāpto yo dhīro nirjitās tena cādhayaḥ // / ///
analyzed: manye na anucitānām tvam ādhīnām padam uttamaḥ āpatsu ca āptaḥ yaḥ dhīraḥ nirjitāḥ tena ca ādhayaḥ
translated: for one who is wise in calamities, by him afflictions are conquered.

original: āptaḥ vicārakārī / na hy ucitasyānucitapadatvaṃ yuktam iti bhāvaḥ // / ///
analyzed: āptaḥ vicāra kārī na hi ucitasya anucita pada tvam yuktam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: One who is wise is one who acts after consideration. The idea is that it is not proper for a suitable person to be in an unsuitable position.🔽Speak quickly as you desire, O sinless one, you will obtain everything,

original: yathābhimatam āśu tvam brūhi prāpsyasi cānagham / sarvam eva punar yena tava bhetsyanti nādhayaḥ // / ///
analyzed: yathā abhimatam āśu tvam brūhi prāpsyasi ca anagham sarvam eva punar yena tava bhetsyanti na ādhayaḥ
translated: by which your afflictions will be destroyed.

original: yena sarvaprāpaṇena // / ///
analyzed: yena sarva prāpaṇena
translated: By which attainment of everything.

original: viśvāmitravākyaṃ sargāntaślokenopasaṃharati
analyzed: viśvāmitra vākyam sarga anta ślokena upasaṃharati
translated: He concludes Viśvāmitra's statement with a verse at the end of the creation:🔽Thus spoken to by the sage, the banner of the Raghu dynasty, having heard the statement full of the play of proper meaning,

original: ity uktam asya sa mune raghuvaṃśaketur ākarṇya vākyam ucitārthavilāsagarbham / tatyāja khedam abhigarjati vārivāhe barhī yathābhyanumitābhimatārthasiddhiḥ
analyzed: iti uktam asya sa muneḥ raghu vaṃśa ketuḥ ākarṇya vākyam ucita artha vilāsa garbham tatyāja khedam abhigarjati vārivāhe barhī yathā abhyanumita abhimata artha siddhiḥ
translated: abandoned his sorrow, like a peacock when the rain-bearing cloud is thundering, with the attainment of the desired object approved.

original: abhyanumitā garjanahetukenānumānena jñātā / abhimatārthasya siddhiḥ yasya / sa / iti śivam // / ///
analyzed: abhyanumitā garjana hetukena anumānena jñātā abhimata arthasya siddhiḥ yasya saḥ iti śivam
translated: known through inference based on the cause of thunder. He who has the accomplishment of the desired object. Thus, auspiciousness.

original: iti śrībhāskarakaṇṭhaviracitāyāṃ śrīmokṣopāyaṭīkāyāṃ vairāgyaprakaraṇe daśamaḥ sargaḥ // / //
analyzed: iti śrī bhāskarakaṇṭha viracitāyām śrī mokṣopāya ṭīkāyām vairāgya prakaraṇe daśamaḥ sargaḥ  /
translated: Thus ends the tenth chapter in the commentary of Shri Bhaskarakant on the text of Shri Moksopāya, in the section on detachment.

original: iti pṛṣṭo munīndreṇa samāśvāsya ca rāghavaḥ / uvāca vacanaṃ cāru dhīrapūrṇārthamantharam // / ///
analyzed: iti pṛṣṭaḥ muni indreṇa samāśvāsya ca rāghavaḥ uvāca vacanam cāru dhīra pūrṇa artha mantharam
translated: Thus asked by the lord of sages and having comforted him, Raghava spoke these sweet words, slow due to his confidence and complete understanding of the meaning.

original: dhīraṃ ca tat pūrṇārthena mantharaṃ nirbharaṃ ca dhīrapūrṇārthamantharam // / ///
analyzed: dhīram ca tat pūrṇa arthena mantharam nirbharam ca dhīra pūrṇa artha mantharam
translated: Slow due to his confidence and complete understanding of the meaning, full of confidence and complete understanding, slow due to his fullness.

original: itaḥ paraṃ vairāgyaprakaraṇārambhaḥ /
analyzed: itas param vairāgya prakaraṇa ārambhaḥ
translated: From here begins the section on detachment.

original: smṛtvā tattvam paramagahanaṃ svasvarūpākhyam ādyaṃ
analyzed: smṛtvā tattvam parama gahanam sva svarūpa ākhyam ādyam
translated: Remembering the supreme truth called one's own nature,

original: spṛṣṭvā mūrdhnā gurucaraṇayor dhūlipuñjam prayatnāt
analyzed: spṛṣṭvā mūrdhnā guru caraṇayoḥ dhūli puñjam prayatnāt
translated: touching with the head the heap of dust from the feet of the guru with effort,

original: kṛtvā devaṃ śaraṇam aniśaṃ vighnarājaṃ ca ṭīkā
analyzed: kṛtvā devam śaraṇam aniśam vighnarājam ca ṭīkā
translated: having taken refuge in the god and the lord of obstacles continuously,

original: vairāgyākhye prakaraṇavare tanyate bhāskareṇa
analyzed: vairāgya ākhye prakaraṇa vare tanyate bhāskareṇa
translated: the commentary on the excellent section called detachment is being composed by Bhaskara.

original: samāśvāsanaparaṃ śrīvasiṣṭhaśrīviśvāmitrayor vākyaṃ śrutvā śrīrāmo hṛdgataṃ vairāgyam prakaṭīkaroti
analyzed: samāśvāsana param śrī vasiṣṭha śrī viśvāmitrayoḥ vākyam śrutvā śrī rāmaḥ hṛd gatam vairāgyam prakaṭīkaroti
translated: Having heard the words of Shri Vasishtha and Shri Vishvamitra, which are full of consolation, Shri Rama reveals the detachment present in his heart.

original: bhagavan bhavatā pṛṣṭo yathāvad adhunā kila / kathayāmy aham ajño 'pi ko laṅghayati sadvacaḥ // / ///
analyzed: bhagavan bhavatā pṛṣṭaḥ yathāvat adhunā kila kathayāmi aham ajñaḥ kaḥ laṅghayati sat vacaḥ
translated: O revered one, I am now indeed asked by you. Although ignorant, I shall speak. Who indeed transgresses the words of the good?

original: bhavateti kulaguruṃ vasiṣṭham praty uktiḥ / kimarthaṃ kathayasīty / atrāha ko laṅghayatīti // / ///🔽svayaṃ kṛtām pratijñāṃ sampādayati
analyzed: bhavatā iti kula gurum vasiṣṭham prati uktiḥ kimartham kathayasi iti atra āha kaḥ laṅghayati iti  svayam kṛtām pratijñām sampādayati
translated: The word to you is a statement to the family teacher Vashishtha. Why do you speak? Here he says, Who transgresses?...

original: ahaṃ tāvad ayaṃ jāto nije 'smin pitṛsadmani / krameṇa vṛddhiṃ samprāptaḥ prāptavidyaś ca saṃsthitaḥ // / ///
analyzed: aham tāvat ayam jātaḥ nije smin pitṛ sadmani krameṇa vṛddhim samprāptaḥ prāpta vidyaḥ ca saṃsthitaḥ
translated: He fulfills the vow he himself made, saying, I, having been born in this very house of my father, having gradually attained growth, and having obtained knowledge, remain...

original: tāvacchabdo vipratipattyabhāvavācakaḥ // / ///
analyzed: tāvat śabdaḥ vipratipatti abhāva vācakaḥ
translated: The word so far expresses the absence of disagreement.

original: tataḥ sadācāraparo bhūtvāham munināyaka / vihṛtas tīrthayātrārtham urvīm ambudhimekhalām // / ///
analyzed: tatas sat ācāra paraḥ bhūtvā aham muni nāyaka vihṛtaḥ tīrtha yātrā artham urvīm ambudhi mekhalām
translated: Then, becoming devoted to good conduct, I, O leader of sages, wandered for the sake of pilgrimage, over the earth girdled by the ocean.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: etāvatātha kālena saṃsārāsthām imām mama / svaviveko jahārāntar oghas taṭalatām iva // / ///
analyzed: etāvatā atha kālena saṃsāra āsthām imām mama sva vivekaḥ jahāra antar oghaḥ taṭa latām iva
translated: In this much time, my attachment to worldly existence, like a creeper on the bank by a flood, was carried away by my own discrimination within.

original: svavivekaḥ ko 'ham iti vicāraḥ // / ///
analyzed: sva vivekaḥ kaḥ ham iti vicāraḥ
translated: One's own discrimination is the investigation of Who am I?

original: vivekena parītātmā tenāhaṃ tad anu svayam / bhoganīrasayā buddhyā pravicāritavān idam // / ///
analyzed: vivekena parīta ātmā tena aham tat anu svayam bhoga nīrasayā buddhyā pravicāritavān idam
translated: With my mind restrained by discrimination, I myself, with a mind disgusted with enjoyments, have pondered over this.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: (The rest is) clear.

original: kiṃ tvayā pravicāritam ity / atrāha
analyzed: kim tvayā pravicāritam iti atra āha
translated: What have you pondered over? Here he says:

original: kiṃ nāmedaṃ vata sukhaṃ yo 'yaṃ saṃsārasaṃsṛtiḥ / jāyate mṛtaye loko mriyate jananāya ca // / ///
analyzed: kim nāma idam vata sukham yaḥ yam saṃsāra saṃsṛtiḥ jāyate mṛtaye lokaḥ mriyate jananāya ca
translated: What indeed is this so-called happiness, which is the transmigration in saṃsāra? The world is born for death, and dies for birth.

original: vata kaṣṭe / idaṃ sukhaṃ kiṃ nāma bhavati / na bhavatīty arthaḥ / idaṃ kiṃ / saṃsāre
analyzed: vata kaṣṭe idam sukham kim nāma bhavati na bhavati iti arthaḥ idam kim saṃsāre
translated: Vata is an expression of distress. What is this called happiness? It means it does not exist. What is this? In saṃsāra,

original: saṃsṛtiḥ saṃsaraṇaṃ yasya / saḥ tādṛśaḥ / yaḥ ayaṃ lokaḥ / mṛtaye yat jāyate / jananāya
analyzed: saṃsṛtiḥ saṃsaraṇam yasya saḥ tādṛśaḥ yaḥ ayam lokaḥ mṛtaye yat jāyate jananāya
translated: which has the nature of transmigrating. He is such. This world, which is born for death, and

original: ca yan mriyate // / / //
analyzed: ca yat mriyate
translated: which dies for birth.

original: mṛtijananarūpasya saṃsaraṇasya duḥkhatvam uktvā tadāśrayabhūtānām bhāvānāṃ duḥkhayuktatvaṃ kathayati🔽svasthitāḥ sarva eveme sacarācaraceṣṭitāḥ / āpadām patayaḥ pāpā bhāvā vibhavabhūmayaḥ // / ///
analyzed: mṛti janana rūpasya saṃsaraṇasya duḥkha tvam uktvā tad āśraya bhūtānām bhāvānām duḥkha yukta tvam kathayati  sva sthitāḥ sarve eva ime sa carācara ceṣṭitāḥ āpadām patayaḥ pāpāḥ bhāvāḥ vibhava bhūmayaḥ
translated: Having stated the suffering nature of transmigration in the form of death and birth, he says that the entities that are the basis of that are associated with suffering:🔽All these, the abodes of misfortune, the sources of wealth, are indeed the movers of the moving and unmoving world, the abodes of misfortune, the sources of wealth.

original: sacarācaraceṣṭitāḥ calanasthitirūpakriyāyuktāḥ / sarve eveme 'nubhūyamānāḥ / bhāvāḥ
analyzed: sa carācara ceṣṭitāḥ calana sthiti rūpa kriyā yuktāḥ sarve eva ime nubhūyamānāḥ bhāvāḥ
translated: The moving and unmoving world is endowed with the actions of moving and staying. All these, the entities that are experienced,🔽are indeed the movers of the moving and unmoving world.

original: sthāvarajaṅgamarūpāḥ padārthāḥ / āpadām patayaḥ āpadyuktāḥ bhavanti / pūrvaślokoktajananamaraṇarūpaduḥkhāśrayatvād
analyzed: sthāvara jaṅgama rūpāḥ padārthāḥ āpadām patayaḥ āpadi uktāḥ bhavanti pūrva śloka ukta janana maraṇa rūpa duḥkha āśraya tvāt
translated: Things are substances that are either immovable or moving. They are the lords of calamities, they are subject to calamities. The meaning is because they are the basis of suffering in the form of birth and death mentioned in the previous verse.

original: ity arthaḥ / bhāvāḥ kathambhūtāḥ / svasthitāḥ svasmin sthitāḥ / na tu parasparaṃ🔽sambandhayuktāḥ / punaḥ kathambhūtāḥ / vibhavabhūmayaḥ yathāsvaṃ śaktiyuktāḥ // / / //
analyzed: iti arthaḥ bhāvāḥ kathambhūtāḥ sva sthitāḥ svasmin sthitāḥ na tu parasparam  sambandha yuktāḥ punar kathambhūtāḥ vibhavabhūmayaḥ yathāsvam śakti yuktāḥ
translated: How are things? They are self-abiding, abiding in themselves, not connected with each other.🔽Again, how are they? They are the grounds of non-existence, endowed with their own powers.

original: nanu katham bhāvāḥ svasthitāḥ bhavanti / parasparaṃ teṣāṃ nānāvidhasambandhadarśanād ity / atrāha
analyzed: nanu katham bhāvāḥ svasthitāḥ bhavanti parasparam teṣām nānāvidha sambandha darśanāt iti atra āha
translated: But how can things be self-abiding, since they are seen to be mutually related in various ways? To this he says:

original: ayaḥśalākāsadṛśāḥ parasparam asaṅginaḥ / śliṣyante kevalam bhāvā manaḥkalpanayā svayā // / ///
analyzed: ayaḥ śalākā sadṛśāḥ parasparam asaṅginaḥ śliṣyante kevalam bhāvāḥ manaḥ kalpanayā svayā
translated: They are like iron rods, not attached to each other. Things only stick together by their own mental construction.

original: ayam mama putrādiḥ ayam mama pitrādir iti manaḥkalpitena saṅkalpenaiva bhāvānām parasparaṃ sambandho 'sti / na tu paramārthata iti bhāvaḥ // / ///
analyzed: ayam mama putra ādiḥ ayam mama pitṛ ādiḥ iti manaḥ kalpitena saṅkalpena eva bhāvānām parasparam sambandhaḥ sti na tu paramārthataḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The relation between things is only by the mental construction of the idea This is my son, etc., This is my father, etc. The meaning is that it is not ultimately real.

original: nanu manasaḥ katham etāvatī śaktir astīty / atrāha
analyzed: nanu manasaḥ katham etāvatī śaktiḥ asti iti atra āha
translated: But how can the mind have such great power? To this he says:

original: manaḥsamāyattam idaṃ jagad ābhogi dṛśyate / manaś cāsad ihābhāti kena smaḥ parimohitāḥ // / ///
analyzed: manaḥ samāyattam idam jagat ābhogi dṛśyate manaḥ ca asat iha ābhāti kena smaḥ parimohitāḥ
translated: This world, dependent on the mind, is seen to be expansive. And the mind appears unreal here. By what are we deluded?

original: ābhogi vistārayuktam / manasaḥ asattvam asatyabhūtapadārthānusandhānamātrarūpatvena jñeyam // / ///
analyzed: ābhogi vistāra yuktam manasaḥ asattvam asatya bhūta padārtha anusandhāna mātra rūpa tvena jñeyam
translated: Expansive means extensive. The unreality of the mind should be known as being of the nature of mere association with unreal objects.

original: asataiva vayaṃ kaṣṭaṃ vikrītā mūḍhabuddhayaḥ / mṛgatṛṣṇāmbhasā dūre vane mugdhamṛgā iva // / ///
analyzed: asatā eva vayam kaṣṭam vikrītāḥ mūḍha buddhayaḥ mṛgatṛṣṇā ambhasā dūre vane mugdha mṛgāḥ iva
translated: Alas, we foolish ones are miserably sold by the unreal, like bewildered deer in the forest by the water of a mirage.

original: asatā eva / na tu satyabhūtena / manaseti śeṣaḥ // / ///
analyzed: asatā eva na tu satya bhūtena manasā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: By the unreal alone. Not by the real. The rest is the mind.

original: na kenacic ca vikrītā vikrītā iva saṃsthitāḥ / vata mūḍhā vayaṃ sarve janānā api śambaram // / ///
analyzed: na kenacid ca vikrītāḥ vikrītāḥ iva saṃsthitāḥ vata mūḍhāḥ vayam sarve api śambaram
translated: And we, though not sold by anyone, remain as if sold. Alas, all of us people are even deluded about Shambara.

original: śambaram māyām // / ///
analyzed: śambaram māyām
translated: Shambara is illusion.

original: kim eteṣu prapañceṣu bhogā nāma sudurbhagāḥ / mudhaiva hi vayam mohāt saṃsthitā baddhabhāvanāḥ // / ///
analyzed: kim eteṣu prapañceṣu bhogāḥ nāma su durbhagāḥ mudhā eva hi vayam mohāt saṃsthitāḥ baddha bhāvanāḥ
translated: What are these enjoyments, which are extremely unfortunate among these elaborations? For we foolishly remain with bound thoughts due to delusion.

original: eteṣu prapañceṣu madhye / sudurbhagāḥ atiśayena durbhagatvākhyaguṇayuktāḥ / bhogā
analyzed: eteṣu prapañceṣu madhye su durbhagāḥ atiśayena durbhaga tva ākhya guṇa yuktāḥ bhogāḥ
translated: Among these elaborations. Extremely unfortunate, endowed with the quality called extreme misfortune. Enjoyments

original: nāma kim bhavanti / āpātamātraramaṇīyatvāt na kiñcid api bhavantīty arthaḥ / hiśabdaḥ
analyzed: nāma kim bhavanti āpāta mātra ramaṇīya tvāt na kiñcid api bhavanti iti arthaḥ hi śabdaḥ
translated: What are they? They are nothing at all, because they are delightful only for a short time. The word hi (in fact)

original: ataḥśabdārthe / hi ataḥ / vayam eteṣu bhogeṣu / baddhabhāvanāḥ / mohāt mudhaiva saṃsthitāḥ
analyzed: atas śabda arthe hi atas vayam eteṣu bhogeṣu baddha bhāvanāḥ mohāt mudhā eva saṃsthitāḥ
translated: means 'therefore'. Therefore, we are attached to these enjoyments, we remain deluded, for no purpose.

original: vyarthatvāt // / / //
analyzed: vyartha tvāt
translated: Because they are useless.

original: ajñāte bahukālena vyartha eva vayaṃ ghane / mohe nipatitā mugdhāḥ śvabhre mugdhamṛgā iva // / ///
analyzed: ajñāte bahu kālena vyarthe eva vayam ghane mohe nipatitāḥ mugdhāḥ śvabhre mugdha mṛgāḥ iva
translated: For a long time, we have fallen into this thick delusion, which is useless, like foolish animals falling into a pit.

original: mohe bhogabhāvanākhye mohe / bahukālena bahukālaṃ tāvat // / ///
analyzed: mohe bhoga bhāvanā ākhye mohe bahu kālena bahu kālam tāvat
translated: In the delusion called attachment to enjoyments, for a long time, for a long time.

original: kim me rājyena kim bhogaiḥ ko 'haṃ kim idam āgatam / yan mithyaivāstu tan mithyā kasya nāma kim āgatam // / /// BhG I
analyzed: kim me rājyena kim bhogaiḥ kaḥ ham kim idam āgatam yat mithyā eva astu tat mithyā kasya nāma kim āgatam
translated: What is the use of my kingdom? What is the use of enjoyments? Who am I? What has come to me? Let that be false which is false. Whose is what? What has come to whom?

original: yat mithyā bhavati tat mithyaivāstu iti sambandhaḥ // / ///
analyzed: yat mithyā bhavati tat mithyā eva astu iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is: Let that which is false be false indeed.

original: avāntaram upasaṃhāraṃ karoti
analyzed: avāntaram upasaṃhāram karoti
translated: He makes a brief conclusion:

original: evaṃ vimṛśato brahman sarveṣv eva tato mama / bhāveṣv aratir āyātā pathikasya maruṣv iva // / ///
analyzed: evam vimṛśataḥ brahman sarveṣu eva tatas mama bhāveṣu aratiḥ āyātā pathikasya maruṣu iva
translated: Thus, O Brahman, as I reflect in this way, disinterest has arisen in me towards all things, like that of a traveler in deserts.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: svābhimatam āviṣkaroti
analyzed: sva abhimatam āviṣkaroti
translated: He reveals his own opinion:

original: tad etad bhagavan brūhi kim idam parinaśyati / kim idaṃ jāyate bhūyaḥ kim idam parivardhate // / ///
analyzed: tat etat bhagavan brūhi kim idam parinaśyati kim idam jāyate bhūyas kim idam parivardhate
translated: Please tell me this, O Blessed One: What is it that perishes here? What is it that is born again? What is it that grows here?

original: kim iti katham ity asyārthe // / ///
analyzed: kim iti katham iti asya arthe
translated: The words why and how are used in the sense of what is the purpose? and what is the method? respectively.

original: jarāmaraṇam āpac ca jananaṃ sampadas tathā / āvirbhāvatirobhāvair vivartante punaḥ punaḥ // / ///
analyzed: jarā maraṇam āpad ca jananam sampadaḥ tathā āvirbhāva tirobhāvaiḥ vivartante punar punar
translated: Old age, death, and calamities, as well as birth and prosperity, revolve again and again through appearance and disappearance.

original: bhāveṣu iti śeṣaḥ / bhāvair iti itthambhāve tṛtīyā / vivartante rūpāntaraṃ gacchanti // / ///
analyzed: bhāveṣu iti śeṣaḥ bhāvaiḥ iti itthambhāve tṛtīyā vivartante rūpa antaram gacchanti
translated: The rest is in relation to entities. The instrumental case in by entities is in the sense of manner. They revolve, they go to another form.

original: bhāvais tair eva tair eva tucchair vayam ime kila / paśya jarjaratāṃ nītā vātair iva giridrumāḥ // / ///
analyzed: bhāvaiḥ taiḥ eva taiḥ eva tucchaiḥ vayam ime kila paśya jarjara tām nītāḥ vātaiḥ iva giri drumāḥ
translated: But we, alas, are reduced to this state of decrepitude by those very same worthless entities, as if by winds on mountain trees. Look!

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: acetanā iva janāḥ pavanaiḥ prāṇanāmabhiḥ / dhvanantaḥ saṃsthitā vyarthaṃ yathā kīcakaveṇavaḥ // / ///
analyzed: acetanāḥ iva janāḥ pavanaiḥ prāṇa nāmabhiḥ dhvanantaḥ saṃsthitāḥ vyartham yathā kīcaka veṇavaḥ
translated: People, like insentient things, are sustained by the winds named life-force, sounding in vain, like the reeds of Kīcaka.

original: kīcakaveṇavo hi vyarthaṃ dhvananti // / ///
analyzed: kīcaka veṇavaḥ hi vyartham dhvananti
translated: For the reeds of Kīcaka sound in vain.

original: śāmyatīdaṃ kathaṃ duḥkham iti tapto 'smi cintayā / jaraddruma ivogreṇa koṭarasthena vahninā // / ///
analyzed: śāmyati idam katham duḥkham iti taptaḥ smi cintayā jarat drumaḥ iva ugreṇa koṭara sthena vahninā
translated: I am tormented by the thought, How will this suffering cease? Like an old tree with a fire in its hollow, by a fierce [wind].

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: saṃsāraduḥkhapāṣāṇanīrandhrahṛdayo 'py aham / nijalokabhayād eva galadbāṣpair na rodimi // / ///
analyzed: saṃsāra duḥkha pāṣāṇa nīrandhra hṛdayaḥ pi aham nija loka bhayāt eva galat bāṣpaiḥ na rodimi
translated: Although my heart is as hard as a stone, being full of the stones of the misery of the world, I do not weep with tears trickling down, out of fear of my own people.

original: saṃsāraduḥkhāny eva pāṣāṇāḥ / taiḥ nīrandhraṃ hṛdayaṃ yasya / saḥ tādṛśaḥ // / ///
analyzed: saṃsāra duḥkhāni eva pāṣāṇāḥ taiḥ nīrandhram hṛdayam yasya saḥ tādṛśaḥ
translated: The miseries of the world are like stones. He whose heart is full of them, such a one...

original: śūnyasanmukhavṛttīs tu śuṣkarodananīrasāḥ / viveka eva hṛtsaṃstho mamaikānteṣu paśyati // / ///
analyzed: śūnya sat mukha vṛttīḥ tu śuṣka rodana nīrasāḥ vivekaḥ eva hṛd saṃsthaḥ mama ekānteṣu paśyati
translated: But in my solitary places, discrimination alone, which is like a dry tearless weeping, sees my empty face-actions.

original: śūnyā vyarthāś ca tāḥ / sanmukhavṛttayaḥ sanmukhavyāpārāḥ tāḥ / ekānteṣu vivekaikapara evāsmīti bhāvaḥ // / ///
analyzed: śūnyāḥ vyarthāḥ ca tāḥ sat mukha vṛttayaḥ sat mukha vyāpārāḥ tāḥ ekānteṣu viveka eka paraḥ eva asmi iti bhāvaḥ
translated: They are empty and useless. Those face-actions, those facial expressions, in my solitary places, meaning I am solely devoted to discrimination.

original: bhṛśam muhyāmi saṃsmṛtya bhāvābhāvamayīṃ sthitim / dāridryeṇeva subhago dūre saṃsāracintayā // / ///
analyzed: bhṛśam muhyāmi saṃsmṛtya bhāva abhāva mayīm sthitim dāridryeṇa iva subhagaḥ dūre saṃsāra cintayā
translated: Remembering the state full of existence and non-existence, I am greatly confused, like a fortunate one by poverty, far away from worldly thoughts.

original: sthitiṃ jagadākhyāṃ sthitim / ahaṃ ka iva / subhaga iva / yathā subhagaḥ dāridryeṇa muhyati / tathety arthaḥ / ataḥ saṃsāracintayā dūre / sā
analyzed: sthitim jagat ākhyām sthitim aham kaḥ iva subhagaḥ iva yathā subhagaḥ dāridryeṇa muhyati tathā iti arthaḥ atas saṃsāra cintayā dūre sā
translated: The state called the world, the state. What am I like? Like a fortunate one. Just as a fortunate one is confused by poverty, that is the meaning. Therefore, far away from worldly thoughts. That

original: dūre bhavatv ity arthaḥ // / ///
analyzed: dūre bhavatu iti arthaḥ
translated: means let it be far away.

original: evaṃ sāmānyena saṃsārapadārthānāṃ duḥkhadatām uktvā tad viśeṣeṣu pradhānabhūtāyāḥ śriyaḥ kathayati
analyzed: evam sāmānyena saṃsāra padārthānām duḥkha da tām uktvā tat viśeṣeṣu pradhāna bhūtāyāḥ śriyaḥ kathayati
translated: Having thus stated in general the nature of misery of the objects of worldly existence, he speaks of the chief of those, namely, prosperity.

original: mohayanti manovṛttiṃ khaṇḍayanti guṇānalam / duḥkhajālam prayacchanti vipralambhaparāḥ śriyaḥ // / ///
analyzed: mohayanti manaḥ vṛttim khaṇḍayanti guṇa analam duḥkha jālam prayacchanti vipralambha parāḥ śriyaḥ
translated: Prosperities, intent on deception, confuse the functioning of the mind, destroy the fire of virtues, and bestow a net of miseries.

original: mohayanti avivekayuktatāṃ kurvanti / aiśvaryamadagrastā hi pūrvāparavicāraśūnyā eva bhavanti / vipralambhaparāḥ vañcanaparāḥ // / ///
analyzed: mohayanti aviveka yukta tām kurvanti aiśvarya mada grastāḥ hi pūrva apara vicāra śūnyāḥ eva bhavanti vipralambha parāḥ vañcana parāḥ
translated: They confuse, i.e., make one devoid of discrimination. For those seized by the intoxication of prosperity become devoid of consideration of past and future. Prosperities intent on deception, i.e., intent on cheating.

original: evaṃ śriyaḥ duḥkhadatvam uktvā tat pradhānāvayavabhūtasya dhanasyāpi duḥkhadatvaṃ kathayati
analyzed: evam śriyaḥ duḥkha da tvam uktvā tat pradhāna avayava bhūtasya dhanasya api duḥkha da tvam kathayati
translated: Having thus stated the nature of misery of prosperity, he speaks of the nature of misery of wealth, which is a principal component of prosperity.

original: cintānicayavakrāṇi nānandāya dhanāni me / samprasūtakalatrāṇi gṛhāṇy ugrāpadāṃ yathā // / ///
analyzed: cintā nicaya vakrāṇi na ānandāya dhanāni me samprasūta kalatrāṇi gṛhāṇi ugra āpadām yathā
translated: My wealth, crooked with heaps of worries, does not bring joy, like houses with many wives, which are a great calamity.

original: cintānicayenārjanādyartham prayuktena cintāsamūhena / vakrāṇi kuṭilāni / ugrāpadāṃ hi bahukalatrāṇi gṛhāṇi duḥkhāyaiva bhavanti // / ///🔽saṅgraheṇa svāsvāsthyaṃ kathayati
analyzed: cintā nicayena arjana ādi artham prayuktena cintā samūhena vakrāṇi kuṭilāni ugra āpadām hi bahu kalatrāṇi gṛhāṇi duḥkhāya eva bhavanti 🔽saṅgraheṇa sva asvāsthyam kathayati
translated: Crooked, i.e., crooked, due to the heap of worries employed for the sake of acquisition etc. Houses with many wives are indeed a misery.

original: vividhadoṣadaśāparicintanaiḥ satatabhaṅgurakāraṇakalpitaiḥ / mama na nirvṛtim eti mano mune nigaḍitasya yathā vanahastinaḥ // / ///
analyzed: vividha doṣa daśā paricintanaiḥ satata bhaṅgura kāraṇa kalpitaiḥ mama na nirvṛtim eti manaḥ mune nigaḍitasya yathā vana hastinaḥ
translated: like that of a forest elephant that is chained.

original: vividhā yāḥ doṣadaśāḥ / tāsām paricintanaiḥ / kathambhūtaiḥ / satataṃ bhaṅgurāṇi yāni kāraṇāni bhogarūpāṇi kāraṇāni / taiḥ kalpitaiḥ svaviṣayatayā
analyzed: vividhāḥ yāḥ doṣa daśāḥ tāsām paricintanaiḥ kathaṃbhūtaiḥ satatam bhaṅgurāṇi yāni kāraṇāni bhoga rūpāṇi kāraṇāni taiḥ kalpitaiḥ sva viṣaya tayā
translated: The various states of faults, by reflecting on them. Of what kind? By those that are imagined by causes that are always fragile, which are the causes in the form of enjoyments. By those that are imagined as one's own objects,

original: prakaṭīkṛtaiḥ // / ///
analyzed: prakaṭīkṛtaiḥ
translated: that are manifested.

original: sarvadoṣamūlakāraṇabhūtān viṣayān sargāntaślokena nindati
analyzed: sarva doṣa mūla kāraṇa bhūtān viṣayān sarga anta ślokena nindati
translated: In the concluding verse of the creation, he criticizes the objects, which are the root causes of all faults.

original: khalāḥ kāle kāle niśi niśitamohaikamihikā gatāloke loke viṣayahaṭhacaurāḥ sucaturāḥ /🔽pravṛttāḥ prodyuktā diśi diśi vivekaikaharaṇe raṇe śaktās teṣāṃ vadata vibudhāḥ ke
analyzed: khalāḥ kāle kāle niśi niśita moha eka mihikāḥ gata āloke loke viṣaya haṭha caurāḥ su caturāḥ  pravṛttāḥ prodyuktāḥ diśi diśi viveka eka haraṇe raṇe śaktāḥ teṣām vadata vibudhāḥ ke
