translated: It is heavy because it goes to a state of fixed position. Heavy is said because it goes to a state of fixed position.

original: na khidyate na mriyate na tiṣṭhati na gacchati / nāstam eti na codeti mahākalpaśatair api // / ///
analyzed: na khidyate na mriyate na tiṣṭhati na gacchati na astam eti na ca udeti mahā kalpa śataiḥ api
translated: He is not tired, does not die, does not stand, does not go, does not set, and does not rise, even in hundreds of great kalpas.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: kevalaṃ jagadārambhalīlayā ghanahelayā / yāpayaty ātmanātmānam anahaṅkāram ānatam // / ///
analyzed: kevalam jagat ārambha līlayā ghana helayā yāpayati ātmanā ātmānam anahaṅkāram ānatam
translated: He simply sustains himself with himself, without ego, and bowed down, with the play of beginning the world, with a heavy disregard.

original: ghanā helā yasyāṃ / tādṛśyā / yāpayati samāpayati / ahaṅkārābhave hi kālo naśyati / svanāśakrīḍām api svayam eva karotīti bhāvaḥ // / ///
analyzed: ghanā helā yasyām tādṛśyā yāpayati samāpayati ahaṅkāra abhave hi kālaḥ naśyati sva nāśa krīḍām api svayam eva karoti iti bhāvaḥ
translated: In which there is a heavy disregard, with such [disregard], he sustains, he completes. For when ego arises, time is destroyed. The idea is that he himself even does the play of his own destruction.

original: yāminīpaṅkakalilāṃ dinakokanadāvalīm / kriyābhramarikām mandaṃ saraḥsu āropayan sthitaḥ // / ///
analyzed: yāminī paṅka kalilām dina kokanada āvalīm kriyā bhramarikām mandam saraḥsu āropayan sthitaḥ
translated: Placing the lotus-row of the day in the mud of the night, he stands slowly raising the swarm of bees of actions in the lakes.

original: saraḥsu arthāt bhuvanarūpeṣu / āropayan kalpayan / sūryarūpeṇeti śeṣaḥ // / ///
analyzed: saraḥsu arthāt bhuvana rūpeṣu āropayan kalpayan sūrya rūpeṇa iti śeṣaḥ
translated: In the lakes, i.e., in the forms of the worlds. Raising, i.e., imagining. The rest is that with the form of the sun.

original: gṛhītvā bhīṣaṇaḥ kṛṣṇāṃ rajanīṃ jīrṇamārjanīm / ālokakanakakṣodam āharaty abhito 'vanim // / ///
analyzed: gṛhītvā bhīṣaṇaḥ kṛṣṇām rajanīm jīrṇa mārjanīm āloka kanaka kṣodam āharati abhitas vanim
translated: Taking the terrible black night as an old broom, he brings the dust of gold of light to the earth all around.

original: āharati sammārjayati / rātriṃ vidhāya prakāśam upasaṃharatīti bhāvaḥ // / ///
analyzed: āharati sammārjayati rātrim vidhāya prakāśam upasaṃharati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: He brings, i.e., sweeps. Having made night, he withdraws light. This is the idea.

original: sañcārayan kriyāṅgulyā koṇakeṣv arkadīpikām / jagatsadmani kāruṇyāt kva kim astīti vīkṣate // / ///
analyzed: sañcārayan kriyā aṅgulyā koṇakeṣu arka dīpikām jagat sadmani kāruṇyāt kva kim asti iti vīkṣate
translated: Moving the lamp of the sun in the corners with the finger of action, he looks out of compassion, What is where? in the house of the world.

original: koṇakeṣu dikkoṇeṣu / anyo 'pi hi dīpikām prajvālya sadmani kva kim astīti paśyati // / ///
analyzed: koṇakeṣu diś koṇeṣu hi dīpikām prajvālya sadmani kva kim asti iti paśyati
translated: In the corners, i.e., in the cardinal directions. For another person also, having lit a lamp, looks in the house, What is where?

original: prekṣyāhāni nimeṣeṇa sūryākṣṇā pākavanty alam / lokapālaphalāny atti jagajjīrṇavanād ayam // / ///
analyzed: prekṣya ahāni nimeṣeṇa sūrya akṣṇā pākavanti alam lokapāla phalāni atti jagat jīrṇa vanāt ayam
translated: Having seen the ripe fruits of the world in an instant with the sun's eye, he eats them, as if they were the fruits of the world-tree.

original: sūryākṣṇā sūryākhyena cakṣuṣā / ahāni prekṣya kañcit kālam pratīkṣyety arthaḥ // / ///
analyzed: sūrya akṣṇā sūrya ākhyena cakṣuṣā ahāni prekṣya kañcid kālam pratīkṣya iti arthaḥ
translated: With the eye called Surya, i.e. with the sun-like eye. Having looked at the days, i.e. having waited for some time.

original: jagajjīrṇakuṭīkīrṇān arpayaty ugrakoṭare / krameṇa guṇavallokamaṇīn mṛtyusamudgake // / ///
analyzed: jagat jīrṇa kuṭī kīrṇān arpayati ugra koṭare krameṇa guṇavat loka maṇīn mṛtyu samudgake
translated: He gradually throws into the fierce cavity of death the gems of virtuous people scattered in the dilapidated hut of the world.

original: jagajjīrṇakuṭyāṃ kīrṇān vikṣiptān / anyo 'pi hi kuṭyāṃ vikṣiptān maṇīn samudgake 'rpayati // / ///
analyzed: kīrṇān vikṣiptān hi kuṭyām vikṣiptān maṇīn samudgake rpayati
translated: Scattered in the dilapidated hut of the world, thrown about. For another person also throws gems thrown about in a hut into a box.

original: guṇair āpūryate yaiva lokaratnāvalī bhṛśam / bhūṣārtham iva tām aṅge kṛtvā bhūyo nikṛntati // / ///
analyzed: guṇaiḥ āpūryate yā eva loka ratna āvalī bhṛśam bhūṣā artham iva tām aṅge kṛtvā bhūyas nikṛntati
translated: That very row of gems of the world, which is filled with virtues as if for the purpose of ornamenting it, he again cuts off, having placed it on his body.

original: anyo 'pi rājādiḥ ratnāvalīm aṅge kṛtvā līlayā kṛntati // / ///
analyzed: anyaḥ pi rāja ādiḥ ratnāvalīm aṅge kṛtvā līlayā kṛntati
translated: Another person also, like a king, having placed the row of gems on his body, cuts it off playfully.

original: dinahaṃsānusṛtayā niśendīvaramālayā / tārākesarayājasraṃ capalo valayaty alam // / ///
analyzed: dina haṃsa anusṛtayā niśā indīvara mālayā tārā kesarayā ajasram capalaḥ valayati alam
translated: With the garland of night-lotuses followed by the day-geese, with the filaments of stars, the fickle one constantly encircles the world.

original: valayati āvṛttaṃ sampādayati / bhuvanam iti śeṣaḥ // / ///
analyzed: valayati āvṛttam sampādayati bhuvanam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: It encircles, accomplishes, the world, this is the remainder.

original: śailorṇadyudharāśṛṅgajagadūrṇāyusaunikaḥ / pratyaham pibati prekṣya tārāraktakaṇān api // / ///
analyzed: śaila ūrṇa dyudha rāśṛṅga jagat ūrṇā āyu saunikaḥ pratyaham pibati prekṣya tārā rakta kaṇān api
translated: The hunter of the world's deer, with the peaks of mountains as his bow, drinks every day even the red particles of stars, having seen them.

original: śailā eva ūrṇā yasya / tat / tādṛśaṃ / dyudhare dyāvāpṛthivyau eva śṛṅge yasya /
analyzed: śailāḥ eva ūrṇā yasya tat tādṛśam dyu dhare dyāvāpṛthivyau eva śṛṅge yasya
translated: Whose hair is the mountains themselves. That. Such. Whose horns are the heaven and earth themselves.

original: tat / tādṛśaṃ ca / īdṛśaṃ ca yat jagat tad eva ūrṇāyuḥ meṣaḥ / tasya saunikaḥ hiṃsakaḥ // / / //
analyzed: tat tādṛśam ca īdṛśam ca yat jagat tat eva ūrṇāyuḥ meṣaḥ tasya saunikaḥ hiṃsakaḥ
translated: That. Such. And such. The world which is like that is the wool of the ram. The butcher of that is the destroyer.

original: tāruṇyanalinīsoma āyurmātaṅgakesarī / na tad asti na yasyāyaṃ tucchātucchasya taskaraḥ // / ///
analyzed: tāruṇya nalinī somaḥ āyuḥ mātaṅga kesarī na tat asti na yasya ayam tuccha atucchasya taskaraḥ
translated: The moon of the lotus of youth, the lion of the elephant of life, that which does not exist, this thief of the insignificant and the insignificant.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: kalpakelivilāsena piṣṭapātitajantunā / nyagbhāvodbhavahāsena ramate svātmanātmani // / ///
analyzed: kalpa keli vilāsena piṣṭa pātita jantunā nyagbhāva udbhava hāsena ramate sva ātmanā ātmani
translated: With the sport of the play of the kalpa, with the one who has fallen beings ground to powder, with the laughter arising from the state of being suppressed, he delights in his own self.

original: piṣṭāḥ cūrṇīkṛtāḥ / ata eva pātitāḥ jantavo yena / saḥ / tādṛśena / kāla iti śeṣaḥ / tṛtīyāntatrayaṃ svātmanety asya viśeṣaṇatvena yojyam // / ///
analyzed: piṣṭāḥ cūrṇīkṛtāḥ atas eva pātitāḥ jantavaḥ yena saḥ tādṛśena kālaḥ iti śeṣaḥ tṛtīya anta trayam sva ātmanā iti asya viśeṣaṇa tvena yojyam
translated: Ground to powder, reduced to dust. And for that very reason, the beings who have fallen, by whom. He is such. The rest is time. The three in the instrumental case are to be connected as qualifications of his own self.

original: kartā bhoktātha saṃhartā smartā sarvam padaṃ gataḥ / sarvam eva karotīdaṃ na karoti ca kiñcana // / ///
analyzed: kartā bhoktā atha saṃhartā smartā sarvam padam gataḥ sarvam eva karoti idam na karoti ca kiñcana
translated: The doer, the enjoyer, the destroyer, the rememberer, having reached the state of all, does all this, and does not do anything at all.

original: nakiñcidrūpatvāt na kiñcit karaṇaṃ jñeyam // / ///
analyzed: na kiñcid rūpa tvāt na kiñcid karaṇam jñeyam
translated: Because of having the nature of nothing, no instrument should be known as doing anything.

original: sargāntaślokena kālanindāṃ samāpayati
analyzed: sarga anta ślokena kāla nindām samāpayati
translated: With the verse at the end of the creation, he concludes the censure of time.

original: sakalam apy akalākalitāntaraṃ subhagadurbhagarūpadharaṃ vapuḥ / prakaṭayan sahasaiva ca gopayan vilasatīha hi kālabalaṃ nṛṣu // / ///
analyzed: sakalam api a kalā kalita antaram subhaga durbhaga rūpa dharam vapuḥ prakaṭayan sahasā eva ca gopayan vilasati iha hi kāla balam nṛṣu
translated: The power of Time, indeed, shines forth among men, manifesting and suddenly concealing the entire body, which assumes the forms of the fortunate and unfortunate, and which is untouched by the distinction of the whole and the parts.

original: sakalatvākalatvādikaṃ viṣayavibhāgena jñeyaṃ / prakaṭayan gopayan ity atra sarvanāmasthānābhāve 'pi numāgama ārṣaḥ / iti śivam // / ///
analyzed: sakala tva akala tva ādikam viṣaya vibhāgena jñeyam prakaṭayan gopayan iti atra sarvanāmasthāna abhāve pi num āgamaḥ ārṣaḥ iti śivam
translated: The state of being whole or not, etc., should be known according to the division of objects. In the expression manifesting and concealing, even in the absence of the place of the pronoun, the augment nu is archaic. Thus, may there be welfare.

original: iti śrībhāskarakaṇṭhaviracitāyāṃ śrīmokṣopāyaṭīkāyāṃ vairāgyaprakaraṇe dvāviṃśaḥ sargaḥ // / //
analyzed: iti śrī bhāskarakaṇṭha viracitāyām śrī mokṣopāya ṭīkāyām vairāgya prakaraṇe dvāviṃśaḥ sargaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twenty-second chapter in the discourse on renunciation in the commentary on the Moksopāya composed by the illustrious Bhaskarakantha.

original: evaṃ kālanindāṃ kṛtvā kālavilāsaṃ kathayati
analyzed: evam kāla nindām kṛtvā kāla vilāsam kathayati
translated: Having thus criticized Time, he describes the sport of Time:

original: asyoḍḍāmaralīlasya dūrāstasakalāpadaḥ / saṃsāre rājaputrasya kālasyākalitaujasaḥ // / ///
analyzed: asya uḍḍāmara līlasya dūra asta sakala āpadaḥ saṃsāre rāja putrasya kālasya a kalita ojasaḥ
translated: Of this prince of Time, whose play is unrestrained, who has cast far away all limitations, whose power is immeasurable, in this world,

original: asminn ācarato dīnair mugdhair bhūtamṛgavrajaiḥ / ākheṭakaṃ jarjarite jagajjaṅgalajālake // / ///
analyzed: asmin ācarataḥ dīnaiḥ mugdhaiḥ bhūta mṛga vrajaiḥ ākheṭakam jarjarite jagat jaṅgala jālake
translated: In this, as he roams, in this vast net of the jungle of the world, which is worn out, with the flocks of simple, foolish creatures,

original: ekadeśollasaccāruvaḍavānalapaṅkajā / krīḍāpuṣkariṇī ramyā kalpakālamahārṇavaḥ // / ///
analyzed: eka deśa ullasat cāru vaḍavānala paṅkajā krīḍā puṣkariṇī ramyā kalpa kāla mahā arṇavaḥ
translated: The great ocean of the age of dissolution is a delightful lotus pond for his play, with the beautiful Vadavana fire shining in one place.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: kaṭutiktāmlabhūtāḍhyaiḥ sadadhikṣīrasāgaraiḥ / tair eva taiḥ paryuṣitair jagadbhiḥ kālyavartanam // / ///🔽kaṭutiktāmlāḥ atyantatāmasikatāmasikarājasikāḥ / kaṭvādirasaviśeṣayuktāś ca ye bhūtāḥ
analyzed: kaṭu tikta amla bhūta āḍhyaiḥ sa dadhi kṣīra sāgaraiḥ taiḥ eva taiḥ paryuṣitaiḥ jagadbhiḥ kālya vartanam  kaṭu tikta amlāḥ atyanta tāmasika tāmasika rājasikāḥ kaṭu ādi rasa viśeṣa yuktāḥ ca ye bhūtāḥ
translated: with those very same stale worldly things, the morning meal is eaten.🔽Bitter, pungent, and sour are extremely tamasic, tamasic, and rajasic. And those elements that are endowed with the specific tastes such as bitter,

original: carācarāḥ bhūtāḥ siddhadravyāṇi ca / taiḥ āḍhyaiḥ yuktaiḥ / paredyuḥ uṣitaiḥ paryuṣitaiḥ /
analyzed: carācarāḥ bhūtāḥ siddhadravyāṇi ca taiḥ āḍhyaiḥ yuktaiḥ paredyus uṣitaiḥ paryuṣitaiḥ
translated: the moving and unmoving elements, and the perfected substances, are abundant, i.e., endowed with them. Having remained overnight, they are stale.

original: na tu navair ity arthaḥ / kālyavartanam prābhātikabhojanaṃ / asyeti sargādyaślokasthaṃ
analyzed: na tu navaiḥ iti arthaḥ kālya vartanam prābhātika bhojanam asya iti sarga ādya śloka stham
translated: The meaning is not that they are new. The morning meal is the breakfast. This, i.e., the verse at the beginning of creation,

original: sarvatra yojyam // / / //
analyzed: sarvatra yojyam
translated: is to be connected everywhere.

original: caṇḍī caturasañcārā sarvamātṛgaṇānvitā / saṃsāravanavinyastanaraiṇākarṣaṇī vṛkī // / ///
translated: Caṇḍī, moving in the four directions, accompanied by the host of all mothers, is the she-wolf who attracts the deer-like men placed in the forest of worldly existence.

original: asya kālasya caṇḍīti nāmadheyā śaktiḥ / vṛkī bhavatīti sambandhaḥ / mātṛgaṇaḥ prasiddhaḥ / rājaputro 'pi ākheṭakārthaṃ vṛkīm pālayati // / ///
analyzed: asya kālasya caṇḍī iti nāmadheyā śaktiḥ vṛkī bhavati iti sambandhaḥ mātṛ gaṇaḥ prasiddhaḥ rāja putraḥ pi ākheṭaka artham vṛkīm pālayati
translated: The power named Caṇḍī of this time is the she-wolf, is the connection. The host of mothers is well-known. Even a prince keeps a she-wolf for hunting.

original: pṛthvī karatale pṛthvī pānapātrī rasānvitā / kamalotpalakalhāralolajālakamālitā // / ///
analyzed: pṛthvī kara tale pṛthvī pāna pātrī rasa anvitā kamala utpala kalhāra lola jālaka mālitā
translated: The earth is in the palm, the earth is the drinking vessel filled with juice, adorned with a garland of the moving nets of lotuses, blue lotuses, and white lotuses.

original: pṛthvī vistīrṇā // / ///
analyzed: pṛthvī vistīrṇā
translated: The earth is vast.

original: virāvī vikaṭāsphālo nṛsiṃho bhujapañjare / saṭāvikaṭapīnāṃsaḥ kāntaḥ krīḍāśakuntakaḥ // / ///
translated: The man-lion, with a mane of fierce and thick shoulders, is a beloved pet bird in the cage of his arms, roaring and fiercely leaping.

original: nṛsiṃhaḥ narasiṃhaḥ / rājaputrasyāpi vilāsārtham pañjare siṃho bhavati // / ///
analyzed: nṛ siṃhaḥ nara siṃhaḥ rāja putrasya api vilāsa artham pañjare siṃhaḥ bhavati
translated: The man-lion is Narasimha. Even a prince has a lion in a cage for amusement.

original: alābuvīṇāmadhuraḥ śaradvyomāmalacchaviḥ / devaḥ kila mahākālo līlākokilabālakaḥ // / ///
analyzed: alābu vīṇā madhuraḥ śarad vyoma amala chaviḥ devaḥ kila mahākālaḥ līlā kokila bālakaḥ
translated: The god Mahakal, it is said, is a playful young cuckoo, sweet-voiced like a gourd-lute, and with the pure complexion of the autumn sky.

original: mahākālaḥ saṃhārādhikārī devaviśeṣaḥ // / ///
translated: Mahakal is a particular god in charge of destruction.

original: ajasrasphūrjitākāro vāntaduḥkhaśarāśaniḥ / abhāvanāmakodaṇḍaḥ parisphurati sarvataḥ // / ///
analyzed: ajasra sphūrjita ākāraḥ vānta duḥkha śara aśaniḥ abhāva nāma kodaṇḍaḥ parisphurati sarvatas
translated: The bow named Abhavana, which constantly emits the form of thunder and shoots arrows of misery, shines everywhere.

original: vāntāḥ udgīrṇāḥ / duḥkhāny eva śarāśanayaḥ / yena / saḥ / abhāvanāmā cāsau kodaṇḍaḥ abhāvanāmakodaṇḍaḥ // / ///
analyzed: vāntāḥ udgīrṇāḥ duḥkhāni eva śara aśanayaḥ yena saḥ abhāva nāmā ca asau kodaṇḍaḥ abhāva nāma kodaṇḍaḥ
translated: Vomited means ejected. It is so because it shoots arrows of misery. It is also called Abhavana, thus it is the bow named Abhavana.

original: sargāntaślokena kālavilāsavarṇanaṃ samāpayati
translated: With the concluding verse of the creation, he concludes the description of the play of time.

original: anuttamasphuritavilāsavardhito bhraman haran parivilasan vidārayan / jarajjagaj jaraḍhavilolamarkaṭaḥ parisphuradvapur iha kāla īhate // / ///
analyzed: anuttama sphurita vilāsa vardhitaḥ bhraman haran parivilasan vidārayan jarat jagat jaraḍha vilola markaṭaḥ parisphurat vapuḥ iha kālaḥ īhate
translated: The Time, whose body is shining here, strives, increasing the excellent flashing and sport, wandering, taking away, sporting around, tearing, the old world, the old and unsteady monkey.

original: īhate nānāvidhāḥ ceṣṭāḥ karoti / iti śivam // / ///
analyzed: īhate nānāvidhāḥ ceṣṭāḥ karoti iti śivam
translated: He strives, he does various actions. Thus is auspiciousness.

original: iti śrībhāskarakaṇṭhaviracitāyāṃ śrīmokṣopāyaṭīkāyāṃ vairāgyaprakaraṇe trayoviṃśaḥ sargaḥ // / //
analyzed: iti śrī bhāskarakaṇṭha viracitāyām śrī mokṣopāya ṭīkāyām vairāgya prakaraṇe trayoviṃśaḥ sargaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twenty-third chapter in the discourse on renunciation in the commentary on the Moksopāya composed by the illustrious Bhāskara Kaṇṭha.

original: evaṃ kālavilāsam uktvā daivavilāsam prastauti
analyzed: evam kāla vilāsam uktvā daiva vilāsam prastauti
translated: Having thus described the sport of Time, he begins the description of the sport of Destiny.

original: atraiva durvilāsānāṃ cūḍāmaṇir ivāparaḥ / karoty astīti lokena daivaṃ kālaś ca kathyate // / ///
analyzed: atrā eva durvilāsānām cūḍāmaṇiḥ iva aparaḥ karoti asti iti lokena daivam kālaḥ ca kathyate
translated: Here itself, Time and Destiny are spoken of by the world as doing and existing, like another crest-jewel of ill sports.

original: karoti iti kriyākathanam / astīti sattākathanaṃ / kālo 'tra kṛtānto 'bhipretaḥ / tasyaiva daivaparyāyatvāt // / ///
analyzed: karoti iti kriyā kathanam asti iti sattā kathanam kālaḥ tra kṛtāntaḥ bhipretaḥ tasya eva daiva paryāya tvāt
translated: Doing is the description of action, existing is the description of being. Time is meant here as the end of creation, because it is a synonym for Destiny.

original: kriyāmātrād ṛte yasya svaparispandarūpiṇaḥ / nānyad ālakṣyate rūpaṃ karmaṇo na samīhitam // / ///
analyzed: kriyā mātrāt ṛte yasya sva parispanda rūpiṇaḥ na anyat ālakṣyate rūpam karmaṇaḥ na samīhitam
translated: Of him, whose form is mere action, consisting of self-motion, and whose desired action is not seen to be different from mere action,

original: teneyam akhilā bhūtasantatir nityapelavā / tāpena himamāleva nītā vidhuratām bhṛśam // / ///
analyzed: tena iyam akhilā bhūta santatiḥ nitya pelavā tāpena hima mālā iva nītā vidhura tām bhṛśam
translated: is brought to a state of distress by suffering, like a snow garland.

original: yasya daivasya / kriyāmātraṃ vinā / na rūpam ālakṣyate / nāpi karmaṇaḥ samīhitaṃ
analyzed: yasya daivasya kriyā mātram vinā na rūpam ālakṣyate na api karmaṇaḥ samīhitam
translated: Of that God, whose form is not perceived without mere action, and whose desired action

original: karmālambanaṃ kāṅkṣitam / ālakṣyate / kimartham / ayaṃ kiñcit karotīti teneyam bhūtasantatir
analyzed: karma ālambanam kāṅkṣitam ālakṣyate kimartham ayam kiñcid karoti iti tena iyam bhūta santatiḥ
translated: is not seen to be based on action, what is the purpose? That this one does something. Therefore, this series of elements

original: vidhuratāṃ nītā // / / //
analyzed: vidhura tām nītā
translated: is brought to a state of distress.🔽Whatever little of this world's sphere of enjoyment is seen,

original: yad idaṃ dṛśyate kiñcij jagadābhogimaṇḍalam / tat tasya nartanāgāram ihāsāv abhinṛtyati // / ///
analyzed: yat idam dṛśyate kiñcid jagat ābhogi maṇḍalam tat tasya nartana āgāram iha asau abhinṛtyati
translated: that is his dancing hall, in which he dances here.

original: tasya daivasya // / ///
analyzed: tasya daivasya
translated: Of that God,

original: asya nāmāntarakathanābhiprāyeṇāha
analyzed: asya nāma antara kathana abhiprāyeṇa āha
translated: with the intention of mentioning another name of him, he says🔽Bearing the third, very terrible name of Kṛtānta,

original: tṛtīyaṃ ca kṛtānteti nāma bibhrat sudāruṇam / kāpālikavapur mattaṃ daivaṃ jagati nṛtyati // / ///
analyzed: tṛtīyam ca kṛtānta iti nāma bibhrat su dāruṇam kāpālika vapuḥ mattam daivam jagati nṛtyati
translated: the God, intoxicated, dances in the world with a body like a Kāpālika.

original: kāpālikavapuḥ kāpālikatulyaḥ // / ///
analyzed: kāpālika vapuḥ kāpālika tulyaḥ
translated: With a body like a Kāpālika, similar to a Kāpālika.

original: asyaiva sarvādhāratvaṃ kathayati
analyzed: asya eva sarva ādhāra tvam kathayati
translated: He says that this very one is the support of all:🔽O sage, of that Kṛtānta, who dances very much, who is extremely passionate,

original: nṛtyato hi kṛtāntasya nitāntam avirāgiṇaḥ / nityaṃ niyatikāntāyā mune paramakāminaḥ // / ///
analyzed: nṛtyataḥ hi kṛtāntasya nitāntam avirāgiṇaḥ nityam niyati kāntāyāḥ mune parama kāminaḥ
translated: and who is always the great lover of the beloved Niyati,

original: śeṣaḥ śaśikalāśubhro gaṅgāvāhaś ca tau tridhā / upavīte avītābhe ubhe saṃsāravakṣasi // / ///
analyzed: śeṣaḥ śaśi kalā śubhraḥ gaṅgā vāhaḥ ca tau tridhā upavīte avīta ābhe ubhe saṃsāra vakṣasi
translated: The remaining one is Śeṣa, white like the digit of the moon, and the flow of the Ganges. Those two are threefold. On the chest of the world, which is free from darkness, both are the sacred threads.

original: tau kau / śeṣaḥ gaṅgāvāhaś ca / avītābhe śobhāyukte / saṃsāra eva vakṣas / tatra // / ///
analyzed: tau kau śeṣaḥ gaṅgā vāhaḥ ca avīta ābhe śobhā yukte saṃsāraḥ eva vakṣaḥ tatra
translated: What are those two? Śeṣa and the flow of the Ganges. Free from darkness means endowed with beauty. The chest is the world itself. On that...

original: candrārkamaṇḍale hemakaṭake karamūlayoḥ / līlāsarasijaṃ haste brāhmam brahmāṇḍakarṇikam // / ///
analyzed: candra arka maṇḍale hema kaṭake kara mūlayoḥ līlā sarasijam haste brāhmam brahmāṇḍa karṇikam
translated: The orb of the moon and sun are the golden bracelets on the wrists. The lotus of sport in the hand is the Brahman, the pericarp of the universe.

original: brāhmam brahmaṇaḥ āsanabhūtam padmam / brahmāṇḍasya karṇikam karnikābhūtaṃ / tanmadhyavartitvāt // / ///
analyzed: brāhmam brahmaṇaḥ āsana bhūtam padmam brahmāṇḍasya karṇikam karnikā bhūtam tad madhya varti tvāt
translated: The Brahman is the lotus that serves as the seat of Brahman. It is the pericarp of the universe, because it is located in the middle of it.

original: tārābinducitaṃ lolapuṣkarāvartapallavam / ekārṇavapayodhautam ekam ambaram ambaram // / ///
analyzed: tārā bindu citam lola puṣkara āvarta pallavam ekārṇava payaḥ dhautam ekam ambaram ambaram
translated: The single sky, washed by the ocean of water, has the luster of the stars and the moon, and the color of the leaves of the lolapuskarāvarta plant.

original: ambaram ākāśam / ambaraṃ vastram // / ///
analyzed: ambaram ākāśam ambaram vastram
translated: The sky is the space. The sky is the cloth.

original: evaṃrūpasya tasyāgre niyatir nityakāminī / anastamitasaṃrambham ārambhaiḥ parinṛtyati // / ///
analyzed: evaṃrūpasya tasya agre niyatiḥ nitya kāminī an astamita saṃrambham ārambhaiḥ parinṛtyati
translated: In front of such a one, Necessity, the eternal lover, dances with her limbs, her passion unabated.

original: ārambhaiḥ yamaniyamarūpaiḥ / nartakasya samīpe hi nartakī api nṛtyati // / ///
analyzed: ārambhaiḥ yama niyama rūpaiḥ nartakasya samīpe hi nartakī api nṛtyati
translated: With her limbs, in the form of restraint and observance. For the dancer, the dancer also dances nearby.

original: tasyā nartanalolāyā jaganmaṇḍapakoṭare / aruddhaspandarūpāyā āgamāpāyacañcure // / ///🔽cārubhūṣaṇam aṅgeṣu devalokāntarāvalī / āpātālaṃ nabho lambaṃ kavarīmaṇḍalam bṛhat // / ///
analyzed: tasyāḥ nartana lolāyāḥ jagat maṇḍapa koṭare a ruddha spanda rūpāyāḥ āgama apāya cañcure  cāru bhūṣaṇam aṅgeṣu deva loka antara āvalī āpātālam nabhaḥ lambam kavarī maṇḍalam bṛhat
translated: In her, who is fond of dancing, in the womb of the world's stage, whose form is unrestrained movement, and which is fickle with coming and going,🔽The beautiful ornament on her limbs is the series of the worlds of the gods, the large circle of her braid hangs down to the nether regions.

original: devānām yāni lokāntarāṇi / teṣām āvalī aṅgeṣu cārubhūṣaṇam bhavati / nabhaḥ kathambhūtam /
analyzed: devānām yāni lokāntarāṇi teṣām āvalī aṅgeṣu cārubhūṣaṇam bhavati nabhaḥ kathambhūtam
translated: The series of the worlds of the gods is a beautiful ornament on her limbs. How is the sky?

original: āpātālam pātālaṃ tāvat / lambaṃ vyāpakaṃ / nṛtyantyāś ca kavarī lambā bhavati // / / //
analyzed: āpātālam pātālam tāvat lambam vyāpakam nṛtyantyāḥ ca kavarī lambā bhavati
translated: It is as far down as the nether regions, and it hangs down, pervades. And the braid of the dancing one becomes long.

original: narakālī ca mañjīramālā kalakalākulā / protā duṣkṛtasūtreṇa pātālacaraṇe calā // / ///
analyzed: nara kālī ca mañjīra mālā kalakala ākulā protā duṣkṛta sūtreṇa pātāla caraṇe calā
translated: And the anklet garland, full of kalakala sounds, is woven with the thread of evil deeds, and moves on the feet of the nether regions.

original: mañjīramālā kiṅkiṇīmālā // / ///
translated: The anklet garland is the garland of bells.

original: kastūrikātilakakaṃ kriyāsakhyopakalpitam / citritaṃ citraguptena yāme vadanapaṭṭake // / ///
analyzed: kastūrikā tilakakam kriyā sakhyā upakalpitam citritam citraguptena yāme vadanapaṭṭake
translated: The mark of musk, arranged by the friend of action, is painted by Citragupta on the canvas of her face in the Yama world.

original: yāme yamasambandhini / vadanapaṭṭake mukhapaṭṭake / 'rthāt yamaśāsanapaṭṭarūpake
analyzed: yāme yama sambandhini vadana paṭṭake mukha paṭṭake rthāt yama śāsana paṭṭa rūpake
translated: In the Yama world, on the canvas of her face, on the canvas of her face, as it were, in the form of the record of Yama's rule.

original: mukhe / citraguptena citritaṃ citraguptakartṛkaṃ citritaṃ / citraguptalikhitā lipir
analyzed: mukhe citraguptena citritam citragupta kartṛkam citritam citragupta likhitā lipiḥ
translated: On the face. Painted by Citragupta. The mark made by Citragupta. The writing done by Citragupta.🔽Up to this extent. What is the mark of musk? How is it?

original: iti yāvat / kastūrikātilakam bhavati / kathambhūtaṃ / kriyāsakhyā kriyāśaktirūpayā
analyzed: iti yāvat kastūrikā tilakam bhavati kathambhūtam kriyā sakhyā kriyāśakti rūpayā
translated: By the friend of action, by the friend in the form of the power of action.

original: sakhyā / upakalpitam citraguptam āviśya racitam / sakhī hi sakhyās tilakaṃ karoti // / / //
analyzed: sakhyā upakalpitam citraguptam āviśya racitam sakhī hi sakhyāḥ tilakam karoti
translated: Conceived. Created by entering Citragupta. For a friend makes a mark for a friend.

original: kālīrūpam upasthāya kalpānteṣu kriyākulam / nṛtyaty eṣā punar devī sphuṭacchailaghanāravam // / ///
analyzed: kālī rūpam upasthāya kalpa anteṣu kriyā ākulam nṛtyati eṣā punar devī sphuṭat śaila ghana āravam
translated: Having assumed the form of Kali, this goddess dances again at the ends of the kalpas, with the sound of splitting mountains and clouds.

original: kālī kālaśaktiḥ / tasyā rūpam upasthāya āśritya / pūrvavṛttāpekṣayā punar iti prayogaḥ // / ///🔽paścātpralambavibhrāntakaumārarathabarhibhiḥ / netratrayabṛhadrandhrabhūribhāṅkārabhīṣaṇaiḥ // / ///
analyzed: kālī kāla śaktiḥ tasyāḥ rūpam upasthāya āśritya pūrva vṛtta apekṣayā punar iti prayogaḥ  paścāt pralamba vibhrānta kaumāra ratha barhibhiḥ netra traya bṛhat randhra bhūri bhāṅkāra bhīṣaṇaiḥ
translated: Kali is the power of time. Having assumed that form, having resorted to it. The usage of again is in relation to what happened before.🔽Later, with the peacock feathers of the youthful chariot, which hang down and are scattered, and with the loud and abundant trumpeting of the elephants, which are terrifying with their three eyes and large holes,

original: lambalolaśaraccandravitīrṇaharamūrdhajaiḥ / uccaraccārumandāragaurīkavaricāmaraiḥ // / ///
analyzed: lamba lola śarad candra vitīrṇa hara mūrdhajaiḥ uccarat cāru mandāra gaurīka vari cāmaraiḥ
translated: With the hair of Shiva scattered by the hanging and swaying autumn moon, and with the beautiful and slow-moving white chowries of Gauri, which are high and make a rustling sound,

original: uttāṇḍavācalākārabhairavādaratumbakaiḥ / raṇatsahasrarandhrendradehabhikṣākapālakaiḥ // / ///
analyzed: uttāṇḍava acala ākāra bhairava ādara tumbakaiḥ raṇat sahasrarandhra indra deha bhikṣā kapālakaiḥ
translated: With the skulls of the bodies of Indra and the thousand-holed ones, begging for alms, in the form of the dancing and agitated Bhairava, with the sound of the drum.

original: śuṣkā śarīrakhaṭvāṅgabhaṅgair āpūritāmbaram / bhāyayaty ātmanātmānam api kṛṣṇair ghanāsitam // / ///
analyzed: śuṣkā śarīra khaṭvāṅga bhaṅgaiḥ āpūritā ambaram bhāyayati ātmanā ātmānam api kṛṣṇaiḥ ghana asitam
translated: The sky is filled with the dry bones of the body, frightening even one's own self, dark like black clouds.

original: kulakam / śuṣkā śoṣaṇadharmayuktā / prakṛtatvāt iyaṃ niyatiḥ / ātmanā ghanāsitam
analyzed: kulakam śuṣkā śoṣaṇa dharma yuktā prakṛta tvāt iyam niyatiḥ ātmanā ghana asitam
translated: The dry bones are characterized by the quality of drying up. Due to being the subject, this is destiny. One's own self,

original: atyantakṛṣṇam / ātmānam api bhāyayati bhayāviṣṭaṃ karoti / anyeṣāṃ tu kā katheti
analyzed: atyanta kṛṣṇam ātmānam api bhāyayati bhaya āviṣṭam karoti anyeṣām tu kā kathā iti
translated: very dark, frightens even oneself, makes it full of fear. But what to speak of others?

original: bhāvaḥ / ātmānam kathambhūtam / śarīrasya ye khaṭvāṅgabhaṅgāḥ arthāt khaṭvāṅgabhaṅgarūpāḥ
analyzed: bhāvaḥ ātmānam kathambhūtam śarīrasya ye khaṭvāṅga bhaṅgāḥ arthāt khaṭvāṅga bhaṅga rūpāḥ
translated: This is the idea. How is one's own self? The parts of the body, in the form of the dry bones,

original: avayavāḥ / taiḥ āpūritāmbaram / śarīrakhaṭvāṅgaiḥ kathambhūtaiḥ / paścād ityādi /
analyzed: avayavāḥ taiḥ āpūrita ambaram śarīra khaṭvāṅgaiḥ kathambhūtaiḥ paścāt ityādi
translated: are filled with the sky. How are the dry bones of the body? As follows.

original: paścātpralambaḥ ata eva vibhrāntaḥ bhraman / kaumāraḥ kumārasambandhī / rathabarhī
analyzed: paścāt pralambaḥ atas eva vibhrāntaḥ bhraman kaumāraḥ kumāra sambandhī ratha barhī
translated: Hanging behind, and hence wandering, the youthful peacock,

original: yeṣāṃ / taiḥ / bhāṅkārāḥ vātakṛtāḥ jñeyāḥ / lambaś cāsau lolaś ca yaḥ śaraccandras /
analyzed: yeṣām taiḥ bhāṅkārāḥ vāta kṛtāḥ jñeyāḥ lambaḥ ca asau lolaḥ ca yaḥ
translated: whose cries are known to be made by the wind, and the autumn moon, which is hanging and moving,

original: tena vitīrṇāḥ dattāḥ / kṛtā iti yāvat / haravat mūrdhajāḥ yeṣāṃ / taiḥ / yathā harasya
analyzed: tena vitīrṇāḥ dattāḥ kṛtāḥ iti yāvat hara vat mūrdhajāḥ yeṣām taiḥ yathā harasya
translated: By him, given, bestowed, made, is the meaning. Those who have hair like Shiva's.

original: keśāḥ candrakalayā bhāsitāḥ bhavanti / tathāsyāḥ pūrṇena śaraccandreṇeti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: keśāḥ candra kalayā bhāsitāḥ bhavanti tathā asyāḥ pūrṇena śarad candreṇa iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Just as Shiva's hair is illuminated by the digit of the moon, so is this one by the full autumn moon, is the idea.

original: uccaraccārumandārā vilasaccārumandārā / yā gaurīkavarī / sā eva cāmaraṃ yeṣāṃ / taiḥ /
analyzed: uccarat cāru mandārā vilasat cāru mandārā  yā gaurīkavarī sā eva cāmaram yeṣām taiḥ
translated: That which is a row of white cowries, shining with beautiful coral, that is the chowrie of those who have it.

original: uttāṇḍavaḥ cāsau acalākāraḥ / bhairavaḥ mahābhairavaḥ / sa evādaratumbakaḥ ādaraviṣayaḥ
analyzed: uttāṇḍavaḥ ca asau acala ākāraḥ bhairavaḥ mahābhairavaḥ saḥ eva ādara tumbakaḥ ādara viṣayaḥ
translated: That which is a dance, and is of the form of an immovable, terrible, great Bhairava, that itself is the drum of respect, the special musical instrument of respect, of those who have it.

original: vādyabhāṇḍaviśeṣaḥ yeṣāṃ / taiḥ / raṇanti sahasrarandhrāṇi netrarūpāṇi randhrasahasrāṇi
analyzed: vādya bhāṇḍa viśeṣaḥ yeṣām taiḥ raṇanti sahasra randhrāṇi netra rūpāṇi randhra sahasrāṇi
translated: The body of Indra, which has a thousand holes, which are eyes, which has a thousand holes, sounds with them.

original: yasya / tādṛśaḥ yaḥ indradehaḥ / sa eva bhikṣākapālakaṃ yeṣāṃ / taiḥ / tathā kṛṣṇaiḥ /🔽idaṃ ca sthūladṛṣṭyartham bāhyadhyānam uktam / sūkṣmadṛṣṭīn prati tu bhaṅgyā kumārādiṣv
analyzed: yasya tādṛśaḥ yaḥ indra dehaḥ saḥ eva bhikṣā kapālakam yeṣām taiḥ tathā kṛṣṇaiḥ  idam ca sthūla dṛṣṭi artham bāhyadhyānam uktam sūkṣma dṛṣṭīn prati tu bhaṅgyā kumāra ādiṣu
translated: That which is such, that itself is the begging bowl of those who have it. And so with the black ones.

original: api niyatisparśaḥ uktaḥ // / / //
analyzed: api niyatisparśaḥ uktaḥ
translated: And this external meditation is stated for the sake of gross vision. But for those of subtle vision, the touch of destiny is stated figuratively even in Kumara and others.

original: viśvarūpaśiraścakracārupuṣkaramālayā / tāṇḍaveṣu vivalgantī mahākalpeṣu rājate // / ///
analyzed: viśva rūpa śiraḥ cakra cāru puṣkara mālayā tāṇḍaveṣu vivalgantī mahā kalpeṣu rājate
translated: With the beautiful lotus garland of the head-wheel of Visvarupa, she shines in the great kalpas, dancing in the Tandava dances.

original: viśvarūpasya virājo / yat śiraścakraṃ / tad eva cārupuṣkaramālā / tayā // / ///
analyzed: viśvarūpasya virājaḥ yat śiraḥ cakram tat eva cāru puṣkara mālā tayā
translated: The head-wheel of Visvarupa is itself the beautiful lotus garland. With that...

original: pramattapuṣkarāvartaḍamarūḍḍāmarāravaiḥ / tasyāḥ kila palāyante kalpānte tumburādayaḥ // / ///
analyzed: pramatta puṣkara āvarta ḍamara uḍḍāmara āravaiḥ tasyāḥ kila palāyante kalpa ante tumbura ādayaḥ
translated: It is said that at the end of the kalpa, Tumburu and others flee from her, with the loud sounds of the intoxicated Pushkaravartas and Damarus.

original: ḍamaravaḥ vādyabhāṇḍaviśeṣāḥ / uḍḍāmarāḥ udbhaṭāḥ / tumbureti gandharvanāma // / ///
analyzed: ḍamaravaḥ vādya bhāṇḍa viśeṣāḥ uḍḍāmarāḥ udbhaṭāḥ tumburā iti gandharva nāma
translated: Damarus are a kind of musical instrument. Uddamaras are bold. Tumburu is the name of a gandharva.

original: nṛtyato 'nte kṛtāntasya candramaṇḍalahāsinaḥ / tārakācandrakācāruvyomapiñchāvacūlinaḥ // / ///
analyzed: nṛtyataḥ nte kṛtāntasya candra maṇḍala hāsinaḥ tārakā candrakā cāru vyoma piñcha avacūlinaḥ
translated: At the end of the dance of the Destroyer, who laughs with the lunar orb, and whose topknot is the sky-tuft, beautiful with the stars and moon...

original: ekasmiñ śravaṇe dīrghā himavān asti mudrikā / apare 'pi mahāmeruḥ kāntā kāñcanakarṇikā // / ///🔽ante kalpānte / candramaṇḍalam eva hāsaḥ / tadyuktasya / candrakāṇi / / / / tābhiḥ
analyzed: ekasmin śravaṇe dīrghā himavān asti mudrikā apare mahā meruḥ kāntā kāñcanakarṇikā  ante kalpa ante candra maṇḍalam eva hāsaḥ tad yuktasya candrakāṇi tābhiḥ
translated: In one ear is the long earring of the Himalayas, and in the other is the beloved golden earring of Meru.🔽At the end, at the end of the kalpa. The lunar orb itself is the laughter. Of him who is endowed with that. The stars...

original: cāru yat / vyomaiva piñchaṃ / tad avacūlaṃ śirobhūṣaṇaṃ yasya / tādṛśasya / mudrikā
analyzed: cāru yat vyoma eva piñcham tat avacūlam śiraḥ bhūṣaṇam yasya tādṛśasya mudrikā
translated: With those, what is beautiful. The sky itself is the tuft. That is the head ornament of him who has it. Such. The earring...

original: śvetaḥ karṇābharaṇaviśeṣaḥ // / / //
analyzed: śvetaḥ karṇa ābharaṇa viśeṣaḥ
translated: The white ear ornament is a special type of earring.

original: atraiva kuṇḍale lole candrārkau gaṇḍamaṇḍale / lokālokācalaśreṇī sarvataḥ kaṭimekhalā // / ///
analyzed: atra eva kuṇḍale lole candra arkau gaṇḍa maṇḍale lokāloka acala śreṇī sarvatas kaṭi mekhalā
translated: Here itself, the moving earrings are the sun and moon on the cheeks, and the row of Lokāloka mountains all around is the waistband.

original: gaṇḍamaṇḍale gaṇḍabhittau / kaṭisthā mekhalā kaṭimekhalā // / ///
analyzed: gaṇḍa maṇḍale gaṇḍa bhittau kaṭi sthā mekhalā kaṭi mekhalā
translated: On the cheeks, on the cheek walls. The waistband is the waistband.

original: itaś cetaś ca gacchantī vidyudvalayavarṇikā / anilāndolitā bhāti nīradāṃśukapaṭṭikā // / ///
analyzed: itas ca itas ca gacchantī vidyut valaya varṇikā anila āndolitā bhāti nīrada aṃśuka paṭṭikā
translated: The lightning garland, which goes here and there, shines like a silk cloth of clouds, shaken by the wind.

original: vidyudvalaya eva varṇikā bhūṣaṇaviśeṣaḥ yasyās / tādṛśī vidyudvalayavarṇikā // / ///
analyzed: vidyut valayaḥ eva varṇikā bhūṣaṇa viśeṣaḥ yasyāḥ tādṛśī vidyut valaya varṇikā
translated: The lightning garland itself is a special type of ornament, which she has. Such is the lightning garland.

original: musulaiḥ paṭṭisaiḥ śūlaiḥ prāsais tomaramudgaraiḥ / tīkṣṇaiḥ kṣīṇajagadvrātakṛtāntair iva sambhṛtaiḥ // / ///
analyzed: musulaiḥ paṭṭisaiḥ śūlaiḥ prāsaiḥ tomara mudgaraiḥ tīkṣṇaiḥ kṣīṇa jagat vrāta kṛtāntaiḥ iva sambhṛtaiḥ
translated: With mallets, axes, spears, javelins, lances, and hammers, as if collected with sharp weapons that bring an end to the multitude of exhausted worlds.

original: saṃsārabandhanādīrghe pāśe kālakaracyute / śeṣabhogamahāsūtre protair mālāsya śobhate // / ///
analyzed: saṃsāra bandhana adīrghe pāśe kāla kara cyute śeṣa bhoga mahā sūtre protaiḥ mālā asya śobhate
translated: In the long noose of the bondage of worldly existence, which has slipped from the hand of time, it shines with a garland strung on the great thread of Śeṣa's coils.

original: saṃsārabandhanārtham / ā samantād / dīrghe / asya samanantaroktasya / daivāparaparyāyasya kṛtāntasya // / ///
analyzed: saṃsāra bandhana artham ā samantāt dīrghe asya samanantara uktasya daiva apara paryāyasya kṛtāntasya
translated: For the purpose of worldly bondage, in the long one all around, of this just mentioned, which is synonymous with fate, of the end of creation.

original: jīvollasanmakarikāratnatejobhir ujjvalā / saptābdhikaṅkaṇaśreṇī bhujayor asya bhūṣaṇam // / ///
analyzed: jīva ullasat makarikā ratna tejobhiḥ ujjvalā sapta abdhi kaṅkaṇa śreṇī bhujayoḥ asya bhūṣaṇam
translated: The series of bracelets in the form of the seven oceans, resplendent with the brilliance of the gems in the playful makarikās of the living beings, is the ornament on his arms.

original: jīvena ullasantaḥ / sajīvā iti yāvat / makarāḥ yāsāṃ / tāḥ / kaṅkaṇeṣv api makarikāḥ bhavanti / kiṃ tu nirjīvāḥ // / ///
analyzed: jīvena ullasantaḥ sajīvāḥ iti yāvat makarāḥ yāsām tāḥ kaṅkaṇeṣu api makarikāḥ bhavanti kim tu nirjīvāḥ
translated: The makarikās that are playful are those that are alive. Makarikās are also found on bracelets, but they are lifeless.

original: vyavahāramahāvartā sukhaduḥkhaparamparā / rajaḥpūrṇā tamaḥśyāmā romālī tasya rājate // / ///
analyzed: vyavahāra mahā āvartā sukha duḥkha paramparā rajaḥ pūrṇā tamaḥ śyāmā romālī tasya rājate
translated: The series of happiness and sorrow, which is a great whirlpool of worldly transactions, filled with rajas, dark with tamas, and having a row of hair, shines forth on him.

original: vyavahārāṇām mahāvartāḥ punaḥ punar āgamanāni yasyāṃ / sā / tādṛśī sukhaduḥkhaparamparā
analyzed: vyavahārāṇām mahā āvartāḥ punar punar āgamanāni yasyām sā tādṛśī sukha duḥkha paramparā
translated: In which there are great whirlpools of worldly transactions, coming again and again, such is the series of happiness and sorrow.

original: tasya romālī rājate / kathambhūtā / rajaḥpūrṇā rajoguṇabharitā / tathā tamaḥśyāmā
analyzed: tasya romālī rājate kathambhūtā rajaḥ pūrṇā rajaḥ guṇa bharitā tathā tamaḥ śyāmā
translated: How does that series of hair shine forth on him? Filled with rajas, full of the quality of rajas. And dark with tamas,

original: tamoguṇamalinā / romālī api āvartayuktā rajaḥpūrṇā tamaḥśyāmā ca bhavati // / / //
analyzed: tamaḥ guṇa malinā romālī api āvarta yuktā rajaḥ pūrṇā tamaḥ śyāmā ca bhavati
translated: stained with the quality of tamas. Even the series of hair is connected with whirlpools, filled with rajas, and dark with tamas.

original: evamprāyāṃ sa kalpānte kṛtāntas tāṇḍavodbhaṭām / upasaṃhṛtya nṛtyehāṃ sṛṣṭyā saha maheśvaraḥ // / ///
analyzed: evamprāyām sa kalpa ante kṛtāntaḥ tāṇḍava udbhaṭām upasaṃhṛtya nṛtya īhām sṛṣṭyā saha maheśvaraḥ
translated: Having thus contracted at the end of the kalpa, the great dancer of death, along with creation, the great lord ceases the dance.

original: punar hāsyamayīṃ nṛttalīlāṃ sarvasvarūpiṇīm / tanotīmāṃ jarāduḥkhaśokābhinayabhūṣitām // / ///
analyzed: punar hāsya mayīm nṛtta līlām sarva svarūpiṇīm tanoti imām jarā duḥkha śoka abhinaya bhūṣitām
translated: Again, she assumes this form, which is full of the play of dance and laughter, adorned with the acting of old age, sorrow and grief.

original: sṛṣṭyā saha niyatyā saha / punaḥ sargārambhe / imāṃ jagadrūpām // / ///
analyzed: sṛṣṭyā saha niyatyā saha punar sarga ārambhe imām jagat rūpām
translated: Along with creation, along with destiny. Again, at the beginning of creation. This one, having the form of the world.

original: sargāntaślokenaitat samāpayati
analyzed: sarga anta ślokena etat samāpayati
translated: He concludes this with a verse at the end of creation.

original: bhūyaḥ karoti bhuvanāni vanāntarāṇi lokāntarāṇi janajālakakalpanāṃ ca / ācāracārukalanāṃ ca calācalāṃ ca paṅkād yathārbhakajano racanām akhinnaḥ
analyzed: bhūyas karoti bhuvanāni vana antarāṇi loka antarāṇi jana jālaka kalpanām ca ācāra cāru kalanām ca cala acalām ca paṅkāt yathā arbhaka janaḥ racanām akhinnaḥ
translated: Again, he creates the worlds, the ends of the forests, the other worlds, the imagination of the multitude of people, and the very unsteady arrangement of good conduct, like a group of children tirelessly creating forms out of mud.

original: calācalām atyantacalām / iti śivam // / ///
analyzed: cala acalām atyanta calām iti śivam
translated: Very unsteady, extremely unsteady. Thus is auspicious.

original: iti śrībhāskarakaṇṭhaviracitāyāṃ śrīmokṣopāyaṭīkāyāṃ vairāgyaprakaraṇe caturviṃśaḥ sargaḥ // / //
analyzed: iti śrī bhāskarakaṇṭha viracitāyām śrī mokṣopāya ṭīkāyām vairāgya prakaraṇe caturviṃśaḥ sargaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twenty-fourth chapter in the discourse on renunciation in the commentary of the venerable Mokshopaya composed by the venerable Bhaskara Kantha.

original: evaṃ daivavilāsam uktvā phalitam āha
analyzed: evam daiva vilāsam uktvā phalitam āha
translated: Having thus described the play of destiny, he states the conclusion.

original: vṛtte 'sminn eva caiteṣāṃ kālādīnām mahāmune / saṃsāranāmni kaivāsthā mādṛśānām bhavatv iha // / ///
analyzed: vṛtte smin eva ca eteṣām kāla ādīnām mahā mune saṃsāra nāmni kā evā āsthā mādṛśānām bhavatu iha
translated: O great sage, when this has occurred, when these time and others have passed, what faith can people like us have in this world called samsara?

original: ata iti śeṣaḥ / vṛtte carite / ādiśabdena daivādīnāṃ grahaṇam // / ///
analyzed: atas iti śeṣaḥ vṛtte carite ādi śabdena daiva ādīnām grahaṇam
translated: The rest is therefore. And when it has occurred, when it has passed. By the word etc. destiny and others are included.

original: vikrītā iva tiṣṭhāma etair daivādibhir vayam / dhūrtaiḥ prapañcacaturair mugdhā vanamṛgā iva // / ///
analyzed: vikrītāḥ iva tiṣṭhāmaḥ etaiḥ daiva ādibhiḥ vayam dhūrtaiḥ prapañca caturaiḥ mugdhāḥ vana mṛgāḥ iva
translated: like foolish forest animals, by these rogues skilled in deceit.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.🔽This untimely death, with ignoble conduct, is eager to swallow,

original: eṣo 'nāryasamācāraḥ kālaḥ kavalanonmukhaḥ / jagaty avirataṃ lokam pātayaty āpadarṇave // / ///
analyzed: eṣaḥ na ārya samācāraḥ kālaḥ kavalana unmukhaḥ jagati aviratam lokam pātayati āpad arṇave
translated: it constantly throws the world into the ocean of calamity.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.🔽At the end, fate burns the world with terrible actions,

original: dahaty ante durāśābhir daivo dāruṇaceṣṭayā / lokam puṣpanikāśābhir jvālābhir dahano yathā // / ///
analyzed: dahati ante durāśābhiḥ daivaḥ dāruṇa ceṣṭayā lokam puṣpa nikāśābhiḥ jvālābhiḥ dahanaḥ yathā
translated: with flames resembling a flower-vendor, like a fire.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.🔽Destiny, inclined towards rules, is fickle by nature, due to being a woman,

original: dhṛtiṃ vidhurayaty ekāmayadārūpavallabhā / strītvāt svabhāvacapalā niyatir niyamonmukhī // / ///
analyzed: dhṛtim vidhurayati strī tvāt svabhāva capalā niyatiḥ niyama unmukhī
translated: it destroys the beauty of the one form of fortitude.

original: āmayadā rogadāyinī / na rūpeṇa vallabhā arūpavallabhā // / ///
analyzed: āmaya dā roga dāyinī na rūpeṇa vallabhā arūpa vallabhā
translated: Giving disease means giving illness. Not beautiful in form means ugly.🔽Yama swallows the net of beings without break, like a snake the wind,

original: grasate 'viratam bhūtajālaṃ sarpa ivānilam / kṛtāntaḥ karkaśācāro jarāṃ nītvā jagadvapuḥ // / ///
analyzed: grasate viratam bhūta jālam sarpaḥ iva anilam kṛtāntaḥ karkaśa ācāraḥ jarām nītvā jagat vapuḥ
translated: having brought the world's body to old age, with harsh conduct.

original: jagad eva vapuḥ yasya / tādṛśaḥ // / ///
analyzed: jagat eva vapuḥ yasya tādṛśaḥ
translated: One whose body is the world itself.

original: yamanirghṛṇarājendro nārtaṃ nāmānukampate / sarvabhūtadayācāro jano durlabhatāṃ gataḥ // / ///
analyzed: yama nirghṛṇa rāja indraḥ na ārtam nāma anukampate sarva bhūta dayā ācāraḥ janaḥ durlabha tām gataḥ
translated: The king of Yama, merciless, does not take pity on the afflicted. A person who practices compassion towards all beings has become very rare.

original: ārtaṃ dīnam // / ///
analyzed: ārtam dīnam
translated: Afflicted, distressed...

original: sarvā eva mune phalguvibhavā bhūtajātayaḥ / duḥkhāyaiva durantāya dāruṇā lobhabhūmayaḥ // / ///
analyzed: sarvāḥ eva mune phalgu vibhavāḥ bhūta jātayaḥ duḥkhāya eva durantāya dāruṇāḥ lobha bhūmayaḥ
translated: O sage, all the species of beings are indeed endowed with meager resources, only for suffering, for a terrible end, and are terrible grounds for greed.

original: phalguvibhavāḥ nissāravibhavayuktāḥ // / ///
analyzed: phalgu vibhavāḥ nissāra vibhava yuktāḥ
translated: Endowed with meager resources, connected with worthless resources.

original: āyur atyantataralam mṛtyur ekas tu niṣṭhuraḥ / tāruṇyaṃ cātitaralam bālyaṃ jaḍatayā hṛtam // / ///
analyzed: āyuḥ atyanta taralam mṛtyuḥ ekaḥ tu niṣṭhuraḥ tāruṇyam ca ati taralam bālyam jaḍa tayā hṛtam
translated: Life is extremely unsteady, but death is the only one that is cruel. Youth is extremely unsteady, and childhood is taken away by dullness.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: Clear...

original: kalākalaṅkito loko bandhavo bhavabandhanam / bhogā bhavamahārogās tṛṣṇā ca mṛgatṛṣṇikā // / ///
analyzed: kalā kalaṅkitaḥ lokaḥ bandhavaḥ bhava bandhanam bhogāḥ bhava mahā rogāḥ tṛṣṇā ca mṛgatṛṣṇikā
translated: The world is tainted by arts, relatives are bondage to existence, enjoyments are great diseases of existence, and craving is a mirage.

original: kalābhiḥ paravañcanākhyābhiḥ kalābhiḥ / kalaṅkitaḥ // / ///
analyzed: kalābhiḥ para vañcana ākhyābhiḥ kalābhiḥ kalaṅkitaḥ
translated: Tainted by arts, by arts known as deceiving others. Tainted...

original: śatravaś cendriyāṇy eva satyaṃ yātam asatyatām / praharaty ātmanaivātmā mana eva manoripuḥ // / ///
analyzed: śatravaḥ ca indriyāṇi eva satyam yātam a satya tām praharati ātmanā eva ātmā manaḥ eva manaḥ ripuḥ
translated: The senses themselves are enemies. Truth has become untruth. The mind itself strikes the self, the mind is indeed the enemy of the mind.

original: ātmā / ātmanā svayam / praharaty ātmānaṃ / durvikalpair iti śeṣaḥ / mana eva aśuddhamanaḥ eva / na tv anyaḥ / manoripuḥ śuddhasya manaso ripuḥ
analyzed: ātmā ātmanā svayam praharati ātmānam durvikalpaiḥ iti śeṣaḥ manaḥ eva aśuddha manaḥ eva na tu anyaḥ manaḥ ripuḥ śuddhasya manasaḥ ripuḥ
translated: The self, by the self, by itself, strikes itself, with evil thoughts, is the remainder. The mind itself, not anything else, is the enemy of the mind, of the pure mind.

original: bhavati // / ///
analyzed: bhavati
translated: It becomes...

original: ahaṅkāraḥ kalaṅkāya buddhayaḥ paripelavāḥ / kriyā duṣphaladāyinyo līlāḥ strīniṣṭhatāṃ gatāḥ // / ///
analyzed: ahaṅkāraḥ kalaṅkāya buddhayaḥ paripelavāḥ kriyāḥ duṣphala dāyinyaḥ līlāḥ strī niṣṭha tām gatāḥ
translated: Egoism is a blemish, the intellects are very weak, the actions give bad results, the sports have become attached to women...

original: paripelavā atīkṣṇāḥ // / ///
analyzed: paripelavāḥ a tīkṣṇāḥ
translated: Very weak, not very sharp...

original: vāñchāviṣayaśālinyaḥ sacamatkṛtayaḥ kṛtāḥ / nāryo doṣapatākinyo rasā nīrasatāṃ gatāḥ // / ///
analyzed: vāñchā viṣaya śālinyaḥ sa camatkṛtayaḥ kṛtāḥ nāryaḥ doṣa patākinyaḥ rasāḥ nīrasa tām gatāḥ
translated: The women are made to have the objects of desire, with wonder, but they are full of faults, the emotions have become tasteless...

original: vāñchāviṣayāś ca tāḥ śālinyaś ca āpātaramaṇīyāś ca / tādṛśyaḥ nāryaḥ / sacamatkṛtayaḥ
analyzed: vāñchā viṣayāḥ ca tāḥ śālinyaḥ ca āpāta ramaṇīyāḥ ca tādṛśyaḥ nāryaḥ sa camatkṛtayaḥ
translated: And they are the objects of desire, and they are elegant, and they are delightful at first, such women. With wonder,

original: camatkārayuktāḥ / kṛtāḥ kalpitāḥ / bhāvitā iti yāvat / kīdṛśyaḥ nāryaḥ / doṣapatākinyaḥ /
analyzed: camatkāra yuktāḥ kṛtāḥ kalpitāḥ bhāvitāḥ iti yāvat kīdṛśyaḥ nāryaḥ doṣa patākinyaḥ
translated: with amazement. Made, imagined, cultivated - to this extent. What kind of women?

original: rāgādidoṣamayatvāt rāgādidoṣapatākinyaḥ / rasāḥ śāstrādiviṣayāḥ abhilāṣāḥ / nīrasatāṃ
analyzed: rāga ādi doṣa maya tvāt rāga ādi doṣa patākinyaḥ rasāḥ śāstra ādi viṣayāḥ abhilāṣāḥ nīrasa tām
translated: Full of faults. Because of being full of faults like passion, they are full of faults like passion. The emotions, the desires for scriptures and other subjects, have become🔽tasteless,

original: śuṣkatāṃ gatāḥ // / / //
analyzed: śuṣka tām gatāḥ
translated: dry.

original: vastv avastutayā cāttaṃ dattaṃ cittam ahaṅkṛtau / abhāvarodhitā bhāvā bhavānto nādhigamyate // / ///
analyzed: vastu avastu tayā ca āttam dattam cittam ahaṅkṛtau abhāva rodhitāḥ bhāvāḥ bhava antaḥ na adhigamyate
translated: The mind, taken as a real thing by the unreal form, and given to the sense of I, the things are obstructed by non-existence, the end of existence is not attained.

original: asmābhiḥ / vastu satyaṃ vastu / avastutayā deho 'ham ity evaṃrūpeṇa avastubhāvenāttaṃ
analyzed: asmābhiḥ vastu satyam vastu  avastu tayā dehaḥ ham iti evaṃrūpeṇa avastu bhāvena āttam
translated: By us. A real thing is a truth, a thing. Taken by the unreal form, as the body is I in that way, by the unreal form,

original: gṛhītaṃ / tathā cittam ahaṅkṛtau dattam ahaṅkāragrastaṃ kṛtam ity arthaḥ / bhāvāḥ
analyzed: gṛhītam tathā cittam ahaṅkṛtau dattam ahaṅkāra grastam kṛtam iti arthaḥ bhāvāḥ
translated: it is grasped. And the mind, given to the sense of I, is made to be seized by the sense of I, is the meaning. The things

original: abhāvarodhitāḥ nāśagṛhītāḥ / na jñātā iti śeṣaḥ / ataḥ bhavāntaḥ nādhigamyate na
analyzed: abhāva rodhitāḥ nāśa gṛhītāḥ na jñātāḥ iti śeṣaḥ atas bhava antaḥ na adhigamyate na
translated: are obstructed by non-existence, seized by destruction. It is not known, is the remainder. Therefore, the end of existence is not attained,

original: prāpyate // / / //
analyzed: prāpyate
translated: it is not reached.

original: tapyate kevalaṃ sādho matir ākulitāntarā / rāgorago vilasati virāgaṃ nopagacchati // / ///
analyzed: tapyate kevalam sādho matiḥ ākulita antarā rāga uragaḥ vilasati virāgam na upagacchati
translated: Only the mind is tormented, O good one, with an agitated interior, passion and non-passion shine forth, it does not attain dispassion.

original: virāgaṃ rāgābhāvaḥ / nopagacchati nāgacchati // / ///
analyzed: virāgam rāga abhāvaḥ na upagacchati na āgacchati
translated: Dispassion is the absence of passion. It does not attain, it does not come.

original: rajoguṇahatā dṛṣṭis tamaḥ samparivardhate / na cādhigamyate sattvaṃ tattvam atyantadūrataḥ // / ///
analyzed: rajaḥ guṇa hatā dṛṣṭiḥ tamaḥ samparivardhate na ca adhigamyate sattvam tattvam atyanta dūrataḥ
translated: The vision struck by the quality of passion, darkness increases all around, and the truth, the reality, is not attained from the farthest distance.

original: tattvam paramārthaḥ // / ///
analyzed: tattvam paramārthaḥ
translated: The truth is the ultimate reality.

original: sthitir asthiratāṃ yātā mṛtir āgamanonmukhī / dhṛtir vaidhuryam āyāti ratir nityam avastuni // / ///
analyzed: sthitiḥ asthira tām yātā mṛtiḥ āgamana unmukhī dhṛtiḥ vaidhuryam āyāti ratiḥ nityam avastuni
translated: Stability has become unstable, death is eager to come, firmness is becoming unsteady, and love is always for worthless things.

original: avastuni avastubhūte dehādau // / ///
analyzed: avastuni avastu bhūte deha ādau
translated: In worthless things, in the body and so on that have become worthless.

original: matir māndyena malinā pātaikaparamaṃ vapuḥ / jvalatīva jarā dehe pravisphūrjati duṣkṛtam // / ///
analyzed: matiḥ māndyena malinā pāta eka paramam vapuḥ jvalati iva jarā dehe pravisphūrjati duṣkṛtam
translated: The mind is polluted by dullness, the body is solely intent on falling, old age seems to be burning in the body, and evil is thundering badly.

original: māndyena jāḍyena // / ///
analyzed: māndyena jāḍyena
translated: By dullness, by sluggishness.

original: yatnenāyāti yuvatā dūre sajjanasaṅgatiḥ / gatir na vidyate kācit kvacin nodeti satyatā // / ///
analyzed: yatnena āyāti yuvatā dūre sat jana saṅgatiḥ gatiḥ na vidyate kācid kvacid nā udeti satyatā
translated: Youth comes with effort, the company of good people is far away, there is no salvation anywhere, truth does not arise anywhere.

original: yuvatā lakṣaṇayā stryāsaktiḥ // / ///
analyzed: yuvatā lakṣaṇayā strī āsaktiḥ
translated: Youth, by metonymy, attachment to women.

original: mano vimuhyatīvāntar muditā dūrato gatā / nojjvalā karuṇodeti dūrād āyāti nīcatā // / ///
analyzed: manaḥ vimuhyati iva antar muditā dūratas gatā nā ujjvalā karuṇā udeti dūrāt āyāti nīca tā
translated: The mind is utterly confused, joy has gone far away, compassion does not shine brightly, lowliness comes from afar.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: Clearly.

original: dhīratādhīratām eti pātotpātaparo janaḥ / sulabho durjanāśleṣo durlabhaḥ sādhusaṅgamaḥ // / ///
analyzed: dhīra tā dhīra tām eti pāta utpāta paraḥ janaḥ sulabhaḥ durjana āśleṣaḥ durlabhaḥ sādhu saṅgamaḥ
translated: People are intent on falling and rising, youthfulness becomes unsteady, association with the wicked is easy, association with the good is difficult.

original: dhīratā adhīratām eti naśyatīty arthaḥ // / ///
analyzed: dhīra tā adhīra tām eti naśyati iti arthaḥ
translated: Youthfulness becomes unsteady, it perishes, is the meaning.

original: āgamāpāyino bhāvā bhāvanā bhavabandhanī / nīyate kevalaṃ kvāpi nityam bhūtaparamparā // / ///
analyzed: āgama apāyinaḥ bhāvāḥ bhāvanā bhava bandhanī  nīyate kevalam kvāpi nityam bhūta paramparā
translated: Things are subject to coming and going; the idea of existence binds one to worldly existence. The mere succession of elements is carried away somewhere by time.

original: nīyate / kāleneti śeṣaḥ // / ///
analyzed: nīyate kālena iti śeṣaḥ
translated: It is carried away by time - this is the remainder.

original: diśo 'pi hi na dṛśyante deśo 'py avyapadeśabhāk / śailā api hi śīryante kaivāsthā mādṛśe jane // / ///
analyzed: diśaḥ pi hi na dṛśyante a vyapadeśa bhāj  śailāḥ api hi śīryante kā eva āsthā mādṛśe jane
translated: Even the directions are not seen, and the country becomes indescribable. Even the mountains are destroyed. What confidence can there be in a person like me?

original: deśaḥ avyapadeśabhāk deśeti vyapadeśaṃ na bhajatīti tādṛk syāt / deśasyāpi deśeti
analyzed: deśaḥ a vyapadeśa bhāj deśa iti vyapadeśam na bhajati iti tādṛś syāt deśasya api deśa iti
translated: The country becomes indescribable, i.e., it would not enjoy the designation country. Even the name country of the country

original: nāma kālena na syād ity arthaḥ / yatredṛśānām īdṛśā daśā bhaviṣyanti tatra mādṛśe
analyzed: nāma kālena na syāt iti arthaḥ yatra īdṛśānām īdṛśāḥ daśāḥ bhaviṣyanti tatra mādṛśe
translated: would not exist due to time - this is the meaning. Where such a state will be for such people, there in a person like me,

original: jane kā eva āsthā ko viśvāsaḥ syād iti bhāvaḥ // / / //
analyzed: jane kā eva āsthā kaḥ viśvāsaḥ syāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: what confidence, what faith, will there be? This is the idea.

original: dravanty api samudrāś ca śīryante tārakā api / siddhā api na sidhyanti kaivāsthā mādṛśe jane // / ///
analyzed: dravanti api samudrāḥ ca śīryante tārakāḥ api siddhāḥ api na sidhyanti kā eva āsthā mādṛśe jane
translated: Even the oceans overflow, and even the stars are destroyed. Even the accomplished ones are not accomplished. What confidence can there be in a person like me?

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: It is clear.

original: adyate 'sattayāpi dyaur bhuvanaṃ cāpi bhajyate / dharāpi yāti vaidhuryaṃ kaivāsthā mādṛśe jane // / ///
analyzed: adyate sattayā api dyauḥ bhuvanam ca api bhajyate dharā api yāti vaidhuryam kā evā āsthā mādṛśe jane
translated: Even the sky is eaten away by non-existence, and even the world is destroyed. Even the earth becomes worthless. What confidence can there be in a person like me?

original: asattayā nāśena / dyaur api adyate grasyate // / ///
analyzed: asat tayā nāśena dyauḥ api adyate grasyate
translated: Even the sky is eaten, devoured, by destruction, which is non-existence.

original: dānavā api dīryanti dhruvo 'py adhruvajīvitaḥ / amarā api māryante kaivāsthā mādṛśe jane // / ///
analyzed: dānavāḥ api dīryanti dhruvaḥ u pi adhruva jīvitaḥ amarāḥ api māryante kā eva āsthā mādṛśe jane
translated: Even the demons are torn apart, even Dhruva has an impermanent life, even the immortals are killed - what reliance can there be in a person like me?

original: māryante / kāleneti śeṣaḥ // / ///
analyzed: māryante kālena iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Are killed. The rest is: by time.

original: śakro 'py ākramyate śakrair yamo 'pi hi niyamyate / vāyor apy asty avāyuṣṭvaṃ kaivāsthā mādṛśe jane // / ///
analyzed: śakraḥ u pi ākramyate śakraiḥ hi niyamyate  vāyoḥ api asti a vāyuḥ tvam kā eva āsthā mādṛśe jane
translated: Even Indra is attacked by new Indras, even Yama is restrained, even Vayu has a time of no wind - what reliance can there be in a person like me?

original: śakraiḥ navīnaiḥ śakraiḥ // / ///
analyzed: śakraiḥ navīnaiḥ śakraiḥ
translated: By new Indras.

original: somo 'pi vyomatām eti mārtāṇḍo 'py eti khaṇḍanam / rugṇatām agnir apy eti kaivāsthā mādṛśe jane // / ///
analyzed: vyoma tām eti mārtāṇḍaḥ pi eti khaṇḍanam rugṇa tām agniḥ api eti kā eva āsthā mādṛśe jane
translated: Even Soma becomes space, even Martanda is broken, even Agni becomes destroyed - what reliance can there be in a person like me?

original: vyomatām / nāśam ity arthaḥ // / ///
analyzed: vyoma tām nāśam iti arthaḥ
translated: Space. The meaning is: destruction.

original: parameṣṭhy apy aniṣṭhāvān harate harim apy ajaḥ / bhavo 'py abhavatāṃ yāti kaivāsthā mādṛśe jane // / ///
analyzed: parameṣṭhī api aniṣṭhāvān harate harim api ajaḥ api abhavaḥ api abhavatām yāti kā evā āsthā mādṛśe jane
translated: Even Brahma, who has no end, takes away even Hari, the unborn one, even Bhava goes to non-existence - what reliance can there be in a person like me?

original: bhavo 'py śrīmahādevo 'pi / abhavatām amahādevabhāvam // / ///
analyzed: a bhavatām a mahādeva bhāvam
translated: Even Bhava, the glorious Mahadeva, goes to the state of non-Mahadeva.

original: kālaḥ śakalatām eti niyatiś cāpi nīyate / kham apy ālīyate 'nante kaivāsthā mādṛśe jane // / ///
analyzed: kālaḥ śakala tām eti niyatiḥ ca api nīyate  kham api ālīyate nante kā evā āsthā mādṛśe jane
translated: Time comes to be measured, and even destiny is led (by him); even the infinite (sky) is limited (by him); what reliance can be placed on a person like me?

original: anante antarahite kasmiṃścid vastuni // / ///
analyzed: anante anta rahite kasmiṃścid vastuni
translated: In some object which is infinite and free from limitations,

original: aśravyāvācyadurdarśatantreṇājñātamūrtinā / bhuvanāni viḍambyante kenāpi bhramadāyinā // / ///
analyzed: a śravya a vācya durdarśa tantreṇa ajñāta mūrtinā bhuvanāni viḍambyante kena api bhrama dāyinā
translated: By some one who is of unknown form, by means of a system which is inexpressable, unspeakable, and difficult to be seen, the worlds are deceived; by some one who causes delusion.

original: aśravyaṃ tathā avācyaṃ tathā durdarśaṃ tantraṃ vañcanopāyaḥ / yasya / tādṛśena / kenāpīti anirvācyenety arthaḥ // / ///
analyzed: aśravyam tathā avācyam tathā durdarśam tantram vañcana upāyaḥ yasya tādṛśena kena api iti anirvācyena iti arthaḥ
translated: By one who has such a system, a means of deception, who is inexpressable, unspeakable, and difficult to be seen. By some one, the meaning is by one who is indescribable.

original: ahaṅkārakalām etya sarvatrāntaravāsinā / na so 'sti triṣu lokeṣu yas teneha na badhyate // / ///
analyzed: ahaṅkāra kalām etya sarvatra antara vāsinā na saḥ sti triṣu lokeṣu yaḥ tena iha na badhyate
translated: Having come to the stage of egoism, dwelling within everything, there is no one in the three worlds who is not bound by him here.

original: dehādau ātmabhāvaḥ ahaṅkāraḥ / tena kenāpīty arthaḥ // / ///
analyzed: deha ādau ātma bhāvaḥ ahaṅkāraḥ tena kena api iti arthaḥ
translated: The idea of the self in the body etc. is egoism. By some one, that is the meaning.

original: śilāśailakaṭapreṣu sāśvasūto divākaraḥ / vanapāṣāṇavan nityam avaśaḥ paridolyate // / ///
analyzed: śilā śaila kaṭapreṣu sa aśva sūtaḥ divākaraḥ vana pāṣāṇa vat nityam avaśaḥ paridolyate
translated: The sun with its horses and charioteer is constantly tossed about like a stone in the forest, helplessly.

original: śilāyuktāḥ śailāḥ śilāśailāḥ / teṣāṃ kaṭaprāḥ samūhāḥ / teṣu paridolyate dolanaṃ kāryate // / ///
analyzed: śilā yuktāḥ śailāḥ śilā śailāḥ teṣām kaṭaprāḥ samūhāḥ teṣu paridolyate dolanam kāryate
translated: Stones are mountains, and their fragments are their collections. In them it is tossed about, i.e. made to swing.

original: dharāgolakam antaḥsthasurāsuragaṇāspadam / veṣṭyate dhiṣṇyacakreṇa pakvākṣoṭam iva tvacā // / ///
analyzed: dharā golakam antar stha sura asura gaṇa āspadam veṣṭyate dhiṣṇya cakreṇa pakva akṣoṭam iva tvacā
translated: The earth-globe, the abode of multitudes of gods and demons within, is enveloped by the circle of the heavenly bodies, like a ripe jujube fruit by its skin.

original: dharāgolakam bhūgolaṃ / veṣṭyate veṣṭanayuktaṃ kriyate / dhiṣṇyacakreṇeti karaṇe tṛtīyā // / ///
analyzed: dharā golakam bhū golam veṣṭyate veṣṭana yuktam kriyate dhiṣṇya cakreṇa iti karaṇe tṛtīyā
translated: The earth-globe is enveloped, i.e., is surrounded, by the circle of the heavenly bodies. The instrumental case is used in dhiṣṇyacakreṇa in the sense of instrument.

original: divi devā bhuvi narāḥ pātāle 'surabhoginaḥ / kalpitāḥ kalpamātreṇa nīyante jarjarāṃ daśām // / ///
analyzed: divi devāḥ bhuvi narāḥ pātāle sura bhoginaḥ kalpitāḥ kalpa mātreṇa nīyante jarjarām daśām
translated: Gods in heaven, men on earth, demons and serpents in the nether world, are imagined to be brought to a decrepit state in a mere kalpa (cosmic cycle).

original: asurabhoginaḥ daityasarpāḥ / kalpamātreṇa kalpamātraparimāṇena // / ///
analyzed: asura bhoginaḥ daitya sarpāḥ kalpa mātreṇa kalpa mātra parimāṇena
translated: Demons and serpents, i.e., Daityas and serpents. In a mere kalpa, i.e., in a kalpa-measure.

original: kāmaś ca jagatīśānaraṇalabdhaparākramaḥ / akrameṇaiva vikrānto lokam ākramya valgati // / ///
analyzed: kāmaḥ ca jagatī īśāna raṇa labdha parākramaḥ akrameṇa eva vikrāntaḥ lokam ākramya valgati
translated: And Kāma, whose prowess was gained in the battle with Īśāna (Śiva), has become valorous without any order (of Śiva), and having conquered the world, he is exulting.

original: īśānena yaḥ raṇaḥ / tena labdhaḥ parākramaḥ / yena / tādṛśaḥ // / ///🔽vasanto mattamātaṅgo madaiḥ kusumavarṣanaḥ / āmoditakakupcakraś ceto nayati vakratām // / ///
analyzed: īśānena yaḥ raṇaḥ tena labdhaḥ parākramaḥ yena tādṛśaḥ  vasantaḥ matta mātaṅgaḥ madaiḥ kusuma varṣanaḥ āmodita kakubh cakraḥ cetaḥ nayati vakra tām
translated: By whom prowess was gained in the battle with Īśāna. By him, who is like that.🔽Spring, the intoxicated elephant, raining the waters of passion, with the bees circling around, leads the mind to crookedness.

original: madaiḥ madavāribhiḥ / vakratāṃ kāmakalāvidagdhatvam / kāmaprasaṅgeneha vasantābhidhānam // / ///
analyzed: madaiḥ mada vāribhiḥ vakra tām kāma kalā vidagdha tvam kāma prasaṅgena iha vasanta abhidhānam
translated: By the waters of passion. Crookedness, i.e., skill in the arts of love. The mention of spring here is in connection with Kāma.

original: anuraktāṅganālokalocanālokitākṛti / spaṣṭīkartum manaḥ śakto na viveko mahān api // / ///
analyzed: anurakta aṅganā āloka locana ālokita ākṛti spaṣṭīkartum manaḥ śaktaḥ na vivekaḥ mahān api
translated: Even great discrimination is not able to purify the mind, whose form is looked at by the eyes of the women who are devoted to it.

original: mahān api vivekaḥ manaḥ spaṣṭīkartuṃ śuddhīkartuṃ / śakto na bhavati / manaḥ kathambhūtaṃ /
analyzed: mahān api vivekaḥ manaḥ spaṣṭīkartum śuddhīkartum śaktaḥ na bhavati manaḥ kathambhūtam
translated: Even great discrimination is not able to purify, to make clear, the mind. What is the mind like?

original: anurakto yaḥ aṅganālokaḥ / tasya yat locanālokitam dṛṣṭipātas / tadvad ākṛtiḥ yasya /
analyzed: anuraktaḥ yaḥ aṅganā ālokaḥ tasya yat locana ālokitam dṛṣṭi pātaḥ tadvat ākṛtiḥ yasya
translated: It is like that which has a form that is looked at by the eyes of the women who are devoted to it, that is looked at by the eyes of the women who are devoted to it.

original: tādṛśam / atyantacalam ity arthaḥ // / / //
analyzed: tādṛśam atyanta calam iti arthaḥ
translated: It is like that, extremely unsteady, is the meaning.

original: paropakārakāriṇyā parārtyā paritaptayā / buddha eva sukhī manye svārthaśītalayā dhiyā // / ///
analyzed: para upakāra kāriṇyā para ārtyā paritaptayā buddhaḥ eva sukhī manye sva artha śītalayā dhiyā
translated: I think only the Buddha is happy, with a mind cool towards his own purpose, burning with the pain of others, acting for the benefit of others.

original: buddhaḥ jñānī / svārthe svaprayojane / śītalayā / na svārthanimittam paritaptayeti yāvat // / ///
analyzed: buddhaḥ jñānī sva arthe sva prayojane śītalayā na sva artha nimittam paritaptayā iti yāvat
translated: The Buddha, the wise one, with a mind cool towards his own purpose, not burning for the sake of his own purpose, is the meaning.

original: utpannadhvaṃsinaḥ kālavaḍavānalapātinaḥ / saṅkhyātuṃ kena śakyante kallolā jīvitāmbudheḥ // / ///
analyzed: utpanna dhvaṃsinaḥ kāla vaḍavānala pātinaḥ saṅkhyātum kena śakyante kallolāḥ jīvita ambudheḥ
translated: By whom can the waves of the ocean of life, which arise and perish, which rush like the submarine fire, be counted?

original: jīvitāmbudheḥ kallolāḥ jīvā ity arthaḥ // / ///
translated: The waves of the ocean of life are the living beings, is the meaning.

original: sarva eva narā mohād durāśāpāśapātinaḥ / doṣagulmakasāraṅgā nigīrṇā janmajaṅgale // / ///🔽doṣagulmakasāraṅgāḥ doṣapriyā ity arthaḥ / mṛgo gulmapriyo bhavati / nigīrṇāḥ grastāḥ / moheneti śeṣaḥ / sāraṅgā api pāśapātinaḥ jaṅgale kirātena
analyzed: sarve eva narāḥ mohāt durāśā pāśa pātinaḥ doṣa gulmaka sāraṅgāḥ nigīrṇāḥ janma jaṅgale  doṣa gulmaka sāraṅgāḥ doṣa priyāḥ iti arthaḥ mṛgaḥ gulma priyaḥ bhavati nigīrṇāḥ grastāḥ mohena iti śeṣaḥ sāraṅgāḥ api pāśa pātinaḥ jaṅgale kirātena
translated: All men, deluded by delusion, entangled in the noose of evil desires, are swallowed up in the forest of birth, like deer fond of thickets, by the thorns of faults.

original: grastā bhavanti // / ///🔽saṅkṣīyate jagati janmaparamparāsu lokasya tair iha kukarmabhir āyur etat / ākāśapādapalatākṛtapāśakalpaṃ yeṣām phalaṃ na hi vicāravido 'pi 🔽vidmaḥ // / ///
analyzed: grastāḥ bhavanti  saṅkṣīyate jagati janma paramparāsu lokasya taiḥ iha ku karmabhiḥ āyuḥ etat ākāśa pādapa latā kṛta pāśa kalpam yeṣām phalam na hi  vidmaḥ
translated: The meaning is: fond of faults. A deer is fond of thickets. Swallowed up means seized. Delusion is understood. Even deer, entangled in the noose, are swallowed up in the forest by hunters.

original: ākāśapādapalatākṛtapāśakalpam asad ity arthaḥ / iha karma kurvantīti bhāvaḥ // / ///
analyzed: ākāśa pādapa latā kṛta pāśa kalpam asat iti arthaḥ iha karma kurvanti iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is: seized. The meaning is: non-existent. The idea is: they perform actions here.

original: sargāntaślokenaitat samāpayati
analyzed: sarga anta ślokena etat samāpayati
translated: He concludes this with a verse at the end of the creation:

original: adyotsavo 'yam ṛtur eṣa tatheha yātrā te bāndhavāḥ sukham idaṃ sa viśeṣabhogaḥ / itthaṃ mudhaiva kalayan svavikalpajālam ālolapelavamatir galatīha
analyzed: adya utsavaḥ yam ṛtuḥ eṣa tathā iha yātrā te bāndhavāḥ sukham idam sa viśeṣa bhogaḥ ittham mudhā eva kalayan sva vikalpa jālam ālola pelava matiḥ galati iha  /
translated: This is the festival, this is the season, this is the journey, these are the relatives, this is the happiness, this is the special enjoyment. Thus, the fickle and unstable-minded world passes away, foolishly considering its own network of imaginations.🔽The world...

original: lokaḥ // / ///
analyzed: lokaḥ
translated: the world...🔽...

original: ālolapelavamatir aticañcalasvalpabuddhir ity arthaḥ / svavikalpajālam ity anena utsavādīnām atyantāsattvam uktam / iti śivam // / ///
analyzed: ālola pelava matiḥ ati cañcala su alpa buddhiḥ iti arthaḥ sva vikalpa jālam iti anena utsava ādīnām atyanta asattvam uktam iti śivam
translated: means having a fickle, small, and unstable mind. By the net of one's own imagination, the utter non-existence of festivals etc. is stated. Thus, auspiciousness.

original: iti śrībhāskarakaṇṭhaviracitāyāṃ śrīmokṣopāyaṭīkāyāṃ vairāgyaprakaraṇe pañcaviṃśaḥ sargaḥ // / //
analyzed: iti śrī bhāskarakaṇṭha viracitāyām śrī mokṣopāya ṭīkāyām vairāgya prakaraṇe pañcaviṃśaḥ sargaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twenty-fifth chapter in the commentary of the venerable Moksopāya composed by the venerable Bhāskarakaṇṭha, in the section on non-attachment.

original: punar api saṃsāradurvilasitam eva kathayati
analyzed: punar api saṃsāra durvilasitam eva kathayati
translated: Again, he speaks of the great sport of worldly existence:

original: anyac ca tātātitarām aramye manorame veha jagatsvarūpe / na kiñcid apy eti tad arthajātaṃ yenātiviśrāntim upaiti cetaḥ // / ///
analyzed: anyat ca tāta atitarām aramye manorame vā iha jagat svarūpe  na kiñcid api eti tat artha jātam yena ati viśrāntim upaiti cetaḥ
translated: And moreover, O father, in this delightful and charming form of the world, which is extremely delightful, there is nothing at all that belongs to that meaning, by which the mind attains complete rest.

original: aham bravīmīti śeṣaḥ / he tātāham anyac ca bravīmi / kim bravīṣīty apekṣāyām āhātitarām
analyzed: aham bravīmi iti śeṣaḥ he tāta aham anyat ca bravīmi kim bravīṣi iti apekṣāyām āha atitarām
translated: The rest is I am speaking. O father, I say something else. When asked What do you say? he says extremely.

original: iti / manorame vā manorame iva / arthajātam padārthasamūhaḥ / atyantaviśrāntau hi
analyzed: iti manorame vā manorame iva artha jātam padārtha samūhaḥ atyanta viśrāntau hi
translated: Thus. Delightful, or as if delightful. The collection of meanings is the group of word meanings. For when there is complete rest,

original: satyām anyārthaviṣayākāṅkṣā na punar udbhaved iti bhāvaḥ // / / //
analyzed: satyām anya artha viṣaya ākāṅkṣā na punar udbhavet iti bhāvaḥ
translated: the desire for objects other than that would not arise again. This is the idea.

original: bālye gate kalpitakelilole vayomṛge dāradarīṣu kīrṇe / śarīrake jarjaratām prayāte vidūyate kevalam eva lokaḥ // / ///
analyzed: bālye gate kalpita keli lole vayaḥ mṛge dāra darīṣu kīrṇe śarīrake jarjara tām prayāte vidūyate kevalam eva lokaḥ
translated: When childhood, with its playful sports, has passed away, and the deer of youth has scattered in the mountain caves, and the body has come to decrepitude, the world is indeed consumed with grief.

original: vayomṛge yauvanākhye mṛge / jarjaratāṃ vṛddhatvaṃ / vidūyate santapyate // / ///
analyzed: vayomṛge yauvana ākhye mṛge jarjara tām vṛddha tvam vidūyate santapyate
translated: The deer of youth, called youth, the deer. Decrepitude, old age. It is consumed, it is tormented.

original: jarātuṣārābhihatāṃ śarīra sarojinīṃ dūratare vihāya / kṣaṇād gate jīvitacañcarīke janasya saṃsārasaro viśuṣkam // / ///
analyzed: jarā tuṣāra abhihatām śarīra sarojinīm dūratare vihāya kṣaṇāt gate jīvita cañcarīke janasya saṃsāra saraḥ viśuṣkam
translated: Having abandoned the lotus pond of the body, struck by the frost of old age, far away, the pond of the world of people is dried up in an instant, when the bee of life has departed.

original: vihāya tyaktvā / jīvitacañcarīke jīvitākhye bhramare // / ///
analyzed: vihāya tyaktvā jīvitacañcarīke jīvita ākhye bhramare
translated: Having abandoned, having left. The bee of life, the bee called life.

original: yadā yadā pākam upaiti nūnaṃ tadā tadeyaṃ navam ātanoti / jarābharānalpanavaprasūnaṃ vijarjarā kāyalatā narāṇām // / ///
analyzed: yadā yadā pākam upaiti nūnam tadā tadā iyam navam ātanoti jarā bhara analpa nava prasūnam vijarjarā kāya latā narāṇām
translated: Whenever it certainly comes to maturity, then this old body vine of men produces new flowers, with old flowers not few due to the burden of old age.

original: nūnaṃ niścaye / navam iti kriyāviśeṣaṇam / tena na paunaruktyam / āścaryaṃ ca pākaṃ gatāyāḥ latāyāḥ navaprasūnasya navam ātananam // / ///
analyzed: nūnam niścaye navam iti kriyāviśeṣaṇam tena na paunaruktyam āścaryam ca pākam gatāyāḥ latāyāḥ nava prasūnasya navam ātananam
translated: Certainly, with certainty. New is an adverb. Therefore there is no repetition. And it is a wonder that a vine that has come to maturity produces new flowers.

original: tṛṣṇānadī sāratarapravāha grastākhilānantapadārthajātā / taṭasthasantoṣasuvṛkṣamūla nikāṣadakṣā vahatīha loke // / ///
analyzed: tṛṣṇā nadī sāratara pravāha grasta akhila ananta padārtha jātā taṭastha santoṣa suvṛkṣa mūla nikāṣa dakṣā vahati iha loke
translated: The river of craving, with a very strong current, carries away all the infinite classes of objects, while the wise who remain at the root of the good tree of contentment are skilled in diving into the water of the world.

original: spaṣṭam // / ///
analyzed: spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

original: śarīranauś carmanibaddhabandhā bhavāmbudhāv ālulitā bhramantī / pravroḍyate pañcabhir indriyākhyair adho vahantī makarair adhīnā // / ///
analyzed: śarīra nauḥ carma nibaddha bandhā bhava ambudhau ālulitā bhramantī pravroḍyate pañcabhiḥ indriya ākhyaiḥ adhas vahantī makaraiḥ adhīnā
translated: The ship of the body, bound with skin, tossed about in the ocean of existence, is submerged by the five called the senses, and carried downwards, being under the control of the crocodiles.

original: pañcabhir indriyākhyaiḥ makaraiḥ śarīranauḥ pravroḍyate magnā sampādyate iti sambandhaḥ / ālulitaṃ samantāc cañcalam // / ///
analyzed: pañcabhiḥ indriya ākhyaiḥ makaraiḥ śarīra nauḥ pravroḍyate magnā sampādyate iti sambandhaḥ ālulitam samantāt cañcalam
translated: The ship of the body is submerged, i.e., made to sink, by the five crocodiles called the senses. It is tossed about, i.e., agitated on all sides.

original: tṛṣṇālatākānanacāriṇo 'mī śākhāśataṃ kāmamahīruheṣu / paribhramantaḥ kṣapayanti kāmam manomṛgā no phalam āpnuvanti // / ///
analyzed: tṛṣṇā latā kānana cāriṇaḥ mī śākhā śatam kāma mahīruheṣu paribhramantaḥ kṣapayanti kāmam manaḥ mṛgāḥ no phalam āpnuvanti
translated: These deer of the mind, wandering in the forest of the vines of craving, indeed roam around in the hundreds of branches of the trees of desire, but do not obtain the fruit.

original: kāmaṃ niścaye / tṛṣṇālatānāṃ yat kānanam / tatra carantīti tādṛśās / tathā paribhramantaḥ
analyzed: kāmam niścaye tṛṣṇā latānām yat kānanam tatra caranti iti tādṛśāḥ tathā paribhramantaḥ
translated: Indeed, in certainty. Those who wander in the forest of the vines of craving are of that kind. Thus, roaming around,

original: paribhramaṇaśīlāḥ / amī manomṛgāḥ / kāmamahīruheṣu kānanagateṣu paramakāmākhyavṛkṣeṣu /
analyzed: paribhramaṇa śīlāḥ amī manaḥ mṛgāḥ kāma mahīruheṣu kānana gateṣu parama kāma ākhya vṛkṣeṣu
translated: having the nature of wandering around, these deer of the mind, in the trees of desire, which are the trees called supreme desire, which are in the forest,

original: gatam śākhāśataṃ / arthāt avāntarakāmarūpaṃ śākhāśataṃ / kṣapayanti cālayanti / svaviṣayaṃ
analyzed: gatam śākhā śatam arthāt avāntara kāmarūpam śākhā śatam kṣapayanti cālayanti sva viṣayam
translated: The hundred branches have gone. That is, the hundred branches of the lower realms of desire and form have gone. And they destroy, that is, move,

original: kurvantīti yāvat / tathāpi phalaṃ no āpnuvanti // / / //
analyzed: kurvanti iti yāvat tathā api phalam no āpnuvanti
translated: their own objects. That is as far as it goes. Still, they do not attain the fruit.

original: kṛcchreṣu dūrāstaviṣādamohāḥ svāmyeṣv anutsiktamanoḥbhirāmāḥ / sudurlabhāḥ samprati sundarībhir anāhatāntaḥkaraṇā mahāntaḥ // / ///
analyzed: kṛcchreṣu dūra asta viṣāda mohāḥ svāmyeṣu su durlabhāḥ samprati sundarībhiḥ anāhata antaḥkaraṇāḥ mahāntaḥ
translated: Those who are far removed from despair and delusion in difficulties, who are delightful to the mind of a lord in prosperous times, who are very difficult to find in the present day by beautiful women, who are great and whose inner minds are not struck -

original: kṛcchreṣu āpatsu / svāmyeṣu sampatsu / anutsiktaṃ darparahitaṃ sat / manaḥ / tenābhirāmāḥ // / ///
analyzed: kṛcchreṣu āpatsu svāmyeṣu sampatsu anutsiktam darpa rahitam sat manaḥ tena abhirāmāḥ
translated: In difficulties, that is, in calamities. In prosperous times, that is, in good fortune. The mind is not puffed up, that is, free from pride. It is delightful by that.

original: taranti mātaṅgaghaṭātaraṅgaṃ raṇāmbudhiṃ ye mayi te na śūrāḥ / śūrās ta eveha manastaraṅgaṃ ye svendriyāmbhodhim imaṃ taranti // / ///
analyzed: taranti mātaṅga ghaṭā taraṅgam raṇa ambudhim ye mayi te na śūrāḥ śūrāḥ te eva iha manaḥ taraṅgam ye sva indriya ambhodhim imam taranti
